I believe that the question can more easily be answered if you turn it on its head: Would it have been better if major banks in the US and subsequently elsewhere in the world had been allowed to collapse, in order to “teach bank managers a lesson” 
  In my mind, the answer is decidedly “no” 
  The financial turmoil, loss of savings and inability to finance day-today operations of businesses that would follow such a collapse, would heavily outweigh the admittedly morally gray zone of saving a financial sector that has overextended its reach.\n Simply put, it would not have been the wealthiest that would have suffered the most 
 It would have been people of low income and small businesses that would in one day end up with absolutely nothing and furthermore and perhaps worse, faced with the complete inability to receive any credit for the foreseeable future; not because they were completely unworthy of it but because there simply wouldn’t be enough of a financial system left to lend them any.\n So, while the solution was not perfect or morally unimpeachable, it was a necessary and (all things considered) cost-effective way of keeping the maximum possible amount of credit available to the market 
 Did people and businesses suffer 
 Of course they did. However, they would have suffered more if the alternative had been chosen

The assumptions used to value other comparable companies could be: 1 
 They are in similar industries 2 
 They are at a similar development of growth During the 2008 Global FInancial Crisis, some companies were trading at very low multiples, despite their healthy free cash flows 
 This was essentially a reflection of lack of liquidity and/or negative investor sentiment 
 At such times, the multiples would not be a true reflection of the value of these companies / shareholder equity value, as the markets would have grossly undervalued these companies, and hence investment opportunities could have been missed 
 Companies that report losses are either at early stage or growth stage, or have massive capital improvement projects 
 As a result, using appropriate ratios for such companies is more critical in order to ascertain a fair value for these companies 
 For early / growth stage companies, perhaps Sales multiple is more relevant; for companies making capital improvement projects, EBITDA multiples are more more relevant

This is a difficult question 
 On the one hand it could seem that the wrong signal was being sent: You can mess up, it doesn't matter - you will be bailed out anyway because you are too big to fail 
 The responsible managers could keep their jobs and even receive bonuses while the rest of the society have to clean up the mess and pay for everything 
 On  the potential impact on the societies had the TARP not been issued, would have been immense 
 Had the governments let the big institutions fail, the string of events following these bankruptcies would more or less freeze the entire system 
 Not only firms would go down, but also individuals and families who had no fault in the misery at all. In the end, the costs would end up with the governments again in form of social welfare and unempoyment benefits 
 Banks ARE facing consequences which have emerged in the aftermath in the form of new and sharpened regulations 
 For example here in Europe, there is the MIFID protecting the investors (and the bankers in the end) 
  Certain investors are no longer able to buy complex financial products for instance, and there has to be an explicit consent from the client before executing investment 
 All in all, I believe that it was the correct decision to bail out the too-big-to fail firms 
 The markets are interconnected to such an extent, that the consequences of letting them fail were (and are) unimaginable

From the asset prices, calculate the return for each period. 
 .i.e 
 Daily returns for daily prices, monthly return for monthly prices 
 Our expected return is the mean of the returns 
 Our risk (volatility) is the standard deviation of the returns 
 If you google, you will find YouTube videos and spreadsheets showing how to calculate returns 
 Some will show how to download stock data from Yahoo 
 One caveat 
 We have to account for any stock splits, dividends, or other distributions when calculating returns 
 Using Yahoo's "adjusted close" prices to calculate returns is an easy way to account for these

I would prefer DCF valuation method over multiple-based valuation method because DCF method considers performance of a company over a longer period of time 
 And thus it gives the output which is close to the actual terms 
 Whereas in multiple-based valuation methods, performance of a company at present is considered which might not justify the real scenario over time 
 E.g Say a company XYZ is running in losses at present 
 But it's ready to launch an excellent product in near future and thus it's anticipated that it'll earn big profits 
 So DCF method will definitely consider this factor in valuation but not the multiple-based valuation method

 Inc. was forced to be acquired by the Bank of America in order to continue to survive 
 In both of these cases, many major players in the banking industry fell and permanently lost their wealth and careers 
 This decimation may have served as a reminder and bitter lesson to bankers and investors (before the bailouts, there was a lot of uncertainty as to who would make it through) 
  So it is perhaps inappropriate to say that the banks came out unscathed 
 On the other hand, the possibility of a bailout, no matter how remote, may act as a form of false insurance in the minds of bankers 
 Therefore, they can underestimate risk or even justify its disregard in the name of short term gains and performance (which is a key driver in competitive fields such as finance and banking) 
  Perhaps an enhanced solution to the bailouts could have included severe penalties to key players (such legal prosecution or personal fines) in order to deter future irrationally risky behaviour 
 Another possibility would have been offering the bailouts only if certain conditions were met, such as the termination of certain employees, a reduction in total compensation for board members and C-suite executives, and/or the mandatory permanent dismissal of current board members and C-suite executives (i.e 
 They cannot be re-elected or appointed) 
  Some might argue that such sanctions would constitute government interference with the private sector and as such should be immediately dismissed 
 Although the premise is correct (that such sanctions are essentially government interference), it should be noted that government bailouts are also a form of government interference and as such, any proponents of the bailouts cannot rationally dismiss the idea of sanctions purely based on the notion of avoiding government interference 
 That is not to say that such sanctions should be automatically adopted alongside a bailout; rather, there needs to be a rational argument based on factual premise and thorough analysis against or for a potential course of action 
 Another measure that could accompany a bailout is developing something similar to the EPA's Superfund, which was collectively funded by major players in the oil and gas industry in order to allocate government funding for managing environmental liabilities that cannot be funded by the parties responsible 
 This fund essentially is a form of government insurance against environmental risks 
 Whether such a system has a place in modern banking is debatable 
 One final consideration is Hyman Minsky's prediction of boom and bust cycles 
 At its most basic level, his theory is that boom and bust cycles are a natural part of the capitalist economy 
 In essence, a bust (or burst of a bubble) causes bankers, investors, and governments to behave more rationally and to better account for risks 
 In some cases, it is even argued that for a number of years following a bust, stakeholders are overly cautious in their assessments of risk 
 However, as the economy begins to prosper, the reign of rationality begins to erode and make way for irrational optimism and speculation 
 In aggregate terms, the market reaches a point of instability, in which the previous upward momentum is overpowered by the effects of irrational exuberance, and then collapses as fear takes over and investors lose confidence 
 The cycle then repeats itself 
 With this consideration in mind, it is possible that history would have repeated itself, in some form or another, regardless of the bailouts - simply due to human nature.\n\n To synthesize an answer to the original question based on the above information is not a simple task 
 In essence, I think that if the net effect (in net present value terms; NPV) of the bailout was positive, then  by all means, it is a rational course of action 
 The first problem comes when determining the actual net benefit based on how this bailout will affect bankers' perception of risk in the future 
 This variable is highly unknown and impossible to determine objectively with absolute certainty 
 The second problem is perhaps the issue of imposing sanctions or taking punitive action against the key players in the banking industry, whether they were bankers or credit rating agencies 
 This again is a difficult question to answer; however, I think it is still important to consider this alternative in NPV terms as to whether it may deter future reckless behaviour 
 Again, quantifying this variable would be difficult 
 Perhaps an approach that I would find most favourable is an analysis (albeit imperfect) showing the rationale for the decision to impose a bailout (with or without sanctions) and its expected net benefit to the national economy in the long run. Such an analysis should clearly state its assumptions and be open for public scrutiny by academics and (disinterested) professionals 
 Although this analysis may not be a perfect representation of reality, it is nonetheless important to attempt to quantify the potential benefits, costs, and risks of any course of action involving such a large sum of money

DCF is long and tedious, and ratios are quick and dirty 
 I initially learned to use ratios as a ballpark figure 
 Like looking at 989 x 32  
  it's close enough to 1000 x 30 = 30,000  
  so I can do a quick calculation and my intuition says to investigate if I get something very different 
 If you are going to use ratios, take some extra time to look at a few. When we use ratios such as P/E, we assume the components are appropriate measures for evaluating the company 
 This may not be the situation though for P/E in early growth companies or restructurings, where they may not have profit but they do have value; in these situations, may be required to use other ratios, such as cashflows or forward looking earnings 
 Likewise, we also assume the components are fairly measured and market information is priced in 
 However, "earnings" may be massaged and contain their own assumptions, or derive from one time events and not solely operations; the quality of earnings must be known 
 Additionally, we may have earnings and profits, but increasing account receivables that may soon lead to cashflow problems 
 Finally, CAPM and P/E are looking at past performance, but we are all familiar with "past performance does not guarantee future results."  P/E is looking at the trailing months, but we need to know if the situation has changed for the future 
 As such, a low P/E may not be a bargain, but in fact a sign that investor's have lost confidence 
 This may be especially prevalent when the market as a whole is reeling (such as the savings-loan, dot-com, or financial crisis); while an undervalued stock will still have a low P/E, it will be mixed in with poor performers and it will be worth doing the extra homework to be assured of your investment's positioning

When you use relative valuation you assume that the market is efficient 
 That is, you assume that "comparable" firms are valued correctly by the market 
 Your thinking is that while the market may be wrong about individual valuations, it is correct "on average."  In reality though, you are subject to the market sentiment/mood 
 An example of this in action was the " _domain_ " bubble when the market bid up the prices/values of internet companies 
 So while a particular web company may have looked cheap (in terms of P/E say) versus other technology stocks, in reality the entire sector was overvalued 
 This created a scenario where relative value told us we should buy that particular stock, but intrinsically it was with little to nothing

 The  _domain_  bubble is a perfect example, in retrospect, of a time when multiple-based valuation methods were inappropriate 
 The technological sector of the market had become particularly severely overvalued due to investor sentiment being clouded by the euphoria of seemingly endless gains in any company purporting to be a "ground floor opportunity" in the emerging dot,com space 
 That said, the dot-com bubble was different from other historical irrational market overvaluations such as the Dutch Tulip bubble, in that the internet during the turn of the millennium was still quite a burgeoning technology of unknown potential thus making any projections of the valuation of otherwise seemingly viable companies especially difficult 
 The current P/E ratio becomes useless when a company reports negative earnings

This question could be better phrased as, "Do governments give bad incentives to bankers?" Put this way, the answer clearly is yes, because we know that people most definitely respond to incentives 
 A banker who knows that his or her bad decisions could lead to the bank's failure will recognize he or she has some skin in the game, whether it be a pension plan, executive stock options, continued employment, or professional reputation 
 Remove enough of this risk of failure thus increases the odds of greater risk-taking by the bankers (hence the banks) in the future 
 Moreover, programs such as TARP penalized good actors in two ways 
 First, it kept afloat competitors whose employees had made bad decisions and thus hindered the natural ability of markets to reward those who make good decisions and punish those who make bad decisions 
 Bankruptcy is analogous to allowing natural forest fires to periodically clear out the underbrush: if you suppress all forest first, the deadwood and underbrush accumulates and, when a fire inevitably breaks out, it is far more catastrophic 
 Second, TARP deliberately forced many sound financial institutions to participate, thus given political cover for helping out failing institutions 
 This action helped fuel the popular misconception that all financial institutions were a bunch of greedy bastards who had upended the economy 
 But fueling populist resentment often leads to bad public policy, such as the illusion that the Dodd-Frank Act actually resolved the "too big to fail" policy when in fact it made it worse in the U.S

Steady, positive returns suggest a lack of variability 
 Consequently, this suggests lower risk 
 To answer your question:  No, the method of calculating risk was not specifically discussed--only a measure of risk in percentage terms (already calculated) 
   The measure of risk that is used, generally, is the standard deviation of returns 
 To your second question, variability of returns (and thus risk) do NOT have to be negative necessarily to suggest risk when examining variability 
 That's where looking at skewness helps better describe the returns (putting them in context) 
   Clearly, unexpectedly large positive returns are good, but this also contributes to the variability calculation (by increasing it) 
   Thus, solely interpreting higher variability of returns as more risky may be premature if the returns are positively skewed (to the right) 
   To your last question, it's probably a worthwhile starting point

 Whereas using DCF, we concentrate on the company's uniqueness in its business

 Such comparison would not hold effective when using the multiple-value based models

 If we were valuing "Sears" we would use a P/E ratio that was the average of the industry Sears was competing with

The first assumption that comes to mind is that of efficient market theory 
 This presumes all information is priced into the value of the stock 
 But there are many who do not subscribe to this theory and thus the market price may not reflect all available information, thus rendering a P/E multiple inadequate for valuation purposes 
 The very idea of finding the fair value of a stock goes directly against efficient market theory because one takes the initial assumption that the market is not valuing the security properly given the available information 
 A company with negative earnings will be challenging to value based on P/E multiples given the fact that a multiple cannot be derived from this negative number 
 In which case one may turn to a different valuation metric 
 However, these multiples are essentially using past and present information 
 Well, as all prospectuses state, in very small print, past results are no guarantee of future results 
 You almost have to use a DCF model, as presumptuous as it may be, since you are investing for the future and need to forecast what possibilities lie in the future 
 Multiples based valuation of related companies also has the problem in that no two companies are the same nor are their products and services 
 While clearly an obvious statement, you essentially are presuming a multiple for valuation purposes based on something else that is not equal but sort of equal 
 At the end of the day it is still an assumption with all its inherent subjective human errors

Using past performance data e.g price earnings, does not necessarily guarantee a solid projection of future earnings 
 It does not take in to account a host of other factors like macro economic variables that may have an impact on the companies results 
 Nor does it take in to account dynamics of of each peer group company which many have a completely different objective which cannot be mirrored by a valuation ratio alone 
 We are constantly reminded of this in capital market data analysis 
 Past results do not guarantee future results

We assume these 'comparable companies' have similar financial structures (assets/liabilities), would be equally impacted by market forces like policies or macroeconomic conditions, as well as that they are not substantially different terms of by whom they ared managed, their products or what they invest in

We are assuming that within an equity market similar companies produce similar flows 
 However the word “similar” and the word “flows” are very fuzzy 
 \n The word “similar companies” implies same products, same product mix, same distribution channels, same cost structure, same growth rate, same patents portfolio, etcetera when in reality this is an impossibility 
 \n The word “similar flows” gives more weight to one measure of activity than others 
 For example if we were to use Enterprise Value to Sales we would empathize Sales but the profitability could be very different

Ratio based comparisons of similar companies (industry, size, etc.) can be a simple way of making a quick evaluation of value 
 One of the assumptions that is not taken into consideration, however, is that the companies may not be “comparable.” In other words, a major new product offering, new manufacturing techniques, or changes in business related practices (marketing or pricing), will not be effectively captured by this method, potentially undervaluing the company in question 
 Take Apple and the iPhone as an example 
 With a focus on design, ease of use, and app integration, this product has outsold competitive smartphones, while commanding a high price 
 Launch of a product of this type will not be adequately captured by ratio methods, which assume the companies and their products are roughly comparable 
 Additionally, there are times (dot com bubble of 2000) when all stocks in a given industry may be strongly over or under valued, causing new companies to have similar valuation errors when a ratio based method is used 
 Additionally, a company reporting a non-typical earnings (or loss) year, may compare badly (undervaluation), but may recover in future years
The current market conditions are extremely important

Let's assume we had two different companies in the same industry 
 For example: the energy market 
 After 2 years, one turns a profit and the other a loss 
 This could be due to any of the following factors:   One invested more into hydro energy than the other, and the previous year had very low rainfall   Both invested the same in solar energy, but one was situated in a cloudier region and hence had less returns for the same cash input    One invested more capital in sales marketing than the other   One of the companies managed to source coal for a lower price   Especially in Information Technology, one might have gained a competitive advantage through invention (refer Google vs Yahoo, Lycos, Altavista) By applying ratios, we are assuming that    What affects one company will affect the other in the exact same way (supply / sale prices, environmental factors, etc.)   The skill of management is the same, and will remain constant   Competition does not exist (i.e 
 A customer growth of one will not result in decline for the other)   Every $ of investment will result in returns whichever of the two companies you invest with   Where two companies sell the same commodity (i.e 
 Their products are exactly the same and differ only in marketing and price), I would be happier to apply multiples methods than in industries where many factors could affect the outcome 
 In the scenario where a company has just posted a loss, I would compare it to other companies in the same industry 
 If others have suffered similar losses, the ratio methods hold true 
 Where only one files a loss, I would look for similarities - is the company I'm trying to evaluate closer (with regards to customer demographics, product, circumstances, etc.) to the one that posted a loss, or to the ones that posted a profit

Multiple-based valuation methods assume that on average comparable companies are priced fairly 
 This assumption breaks down during market bubbles, which may cause rampant overvaluation across an entire market sector

The assumption is that the companies that are publicly traded and hence we have information about their valuation are fairly valued and the price of the share reflects the true price of the firm 
 The dotcom bubble or the more recent housing bubble are two examples in history when the prices of publicly traded companies' shares were not reflecting the true or fair value of these companies 
 The market was overvaluing these companies and therefore all the non publicly traded companies that used them to compare with the multiples method 
 Using the multiples method, the companies that reported a loss will have negative valuations 
 However, this is not the case in the real world because they are valued using expectations, or by their liquidation value (assets - debt) 
  The loss reported can be spontaneous or transitory

Comparable companies should have similar growth\npotential and risk, hence we usually compare firms in the same stage of development and industry 
 When using multiple-based valuation, one assumes that even though markets might misestimate individual stocks, they are correct on average 
 For example,\nwhen one values Ford relative to other large carmakers, he assumes that these companies have been priced accurately (on average) by the market, although it probably misjudged them on an individual basis 
 So a stock might be overvalued on a discounted cash flow basis but undervalued on a multiple-based basis, if the pool of comparable companies used in the later valuation are all\noverpriced by the market 
 In other words, multiple-based valuation reflects the market mood, and in using that the value of an asset can\nresult in values that are too high, when the market is over valuing comparable\nfirms, or too low, when it is under valuing these firms 
 A recent example were multiple-based valuation would be a poor method is the  _domain_  crash, when tech companies were extremely overpriced by the market 
 Finally, when the earnings per share are negative, the price\nearnings ratio for a company is not meaningful and shouldn't be included in the comparison of other comparable firms

P/E method may not work when we valuate companies from sector which is (as a whole) overvaluated like tech companies

When we use multiple based methods we make the assumption that the prices of reference companies are fair and they are not over- or underestimated

 Normally, we can avoid the impact of an unfair price of some of our reference companies by using as many companies as possible

When we use ratios we observe on the market (like price-to-earnings) to value other comparable companies we assume that the companies will have the same financial performance 
 Yes there are so many instances that I felt not comfortable using these methods because the companies may have the same financial structure, they can be in the same industry, be in the same growth stage but they are things that can still make a big difference as regarding the financial performance of those companies 
 For example, the quality of the management, the corporate governance structure, the human resources 
 Etc. These are examples of characteristics inherent to companies that are seldom mentioned but that can make a huge difference in their financial performance 
 I therefore really feel uneasy at times when using the ratios related to one company to evaluate another company 
 Because companies are unique; they are like human beings with their own unique DNA, unique culture and that can make a difference, a big differene for that matter

Firstly, we have to make sure that the company we are considering is in the same development stage than the comparable firms in order to successfully use multiple-based valuation 
 We are assuming that the present situation of comparable companies (and their multiples) are representative of what is going to happen 
 In case of a crash ("black swan"), any result would prove wrong 
 For a company which just reported a loss, it would be necessary to understand why they had a loss (development stage, exceptional circumstances, etc.), and it would not be reasonable to use multiple-based valuation considering the multiples of companies which are having positive earnings

When we use multiples like the P/E ratio of similar companies to estimate the value of a particular firm we are interested in, it is absolutely crucial to assume that the chosen reference companies are valued at a fair price 
 That is, that reference companies are neither under- nor overvalued 
 Without that premise, there is no way to obtain a fair valuation using the multiples method 
 For example during the dotcom bubble, internet companies were traded at P/E ratios of up to 100. Those firms were greatly overvalued at that time and using them as a reference would have resulted in a huge overvaluation 
 This gets further distorted when companies report negative earnings, in which case the P/E ratio would naturally turn negative too, resulting in a massive undervaluation of a stock
Those measures were needed as an emergency measures, but they can not be maintained for ever, the situation has to be normalized

In using market-based ratios to compare companies to their peers, we assume that market transaction prices represent a rational risk-based assessment of the fair value of a company 
 However, in the short term, other factors may influence what buyers are willing to pay for a share of the company, like investment alternatives and general market conditions affected by short term political and economic events 
 Economic crises (like the subprime credit crash) and negative events involving a single company (like an Enron) might very likely affect the price of a company in the short run. Likewise, temporary losses might make earnings a meaningless metric for fair market value

It seems to me that Federal Reserve had no other choice, otherwise the whole economy would have collapsed probably 
 But I admit that this policy gives wrong incentives to the market and banks in particular 
 The only way out of this loop, seems to be the abolition of fractional reserve banking and requiring the banks to hold 100% reserves for the checking account of people and for this service they can charge a percentage of the transactions, services that are already being provided by companies  like PayPal and others 
 The banks can accept long term deposits or can have other investments but these investments should be done on separate balance sheets to ensure that even if there is a bubble and the bank loses a lot of its assets, the checking accounts are not touched 
 This way the government need not to provide any insurance to the banks on the investments that bank do 
 In fact the most  important phenomenon that we observe during failures in the market like the 2008 crisis is not that a bubble bursts, it is the fact that regular businesses that have checking accounts with those banks can not do  business anymore 
 If we separate investment and checking accounts, we can avoid this problem

Bailouts are always a difficult choice for a policy maker 
 As they "save the bad guys" employing public resources, they are understandably criticised for perversing managers' incentives and incentivising reckless behaviors.\n This is the reason why the European Union has passed the Bank Recovery and  Resolution Directive, whose declared aim is to put an end to the use of taxpayers' money to rescue failing istitution, setting up the scene for bail-in tools and the creation of a resolution fund financed through a levy on banks  
  This is also the path taken by international bodies, as the Financial Stability Board, with the recent publication of the TLAC 
 However, in hindsight, the choice of the US federal goverment has been probabily the best one,cost-wise 
 Thanks to the TARP, the US banking sector was freshened up and lending istitutions were able to resume credit provision to households and corporations 
 On the other hand, here in Europe, Cocos bonds and other bailin-able istruments have been shunned by investors, and the huge amount of Non Performing Assets is still impinging on bank lending 
 \n To conlude, I think that the less painful solution would have been to wind down some istitutions, clean up the balance sheet of those banks that were still solvent, and bearing with the criticism of incentivising banks' risky behaviour

 European banks need a magic wand

Multiple-based valuation only considers financial information of similar companies 
 It doesn't consider how similar its products, strategies, operations and target clients are (Goedhart et al., 2005) 
  So, even though in theory Apple and Microsoft may be very similar companies, since the products, earnings, and stock price may be the same, but in reality their strategies are completely different, Apple focuses on aesthetics and flow of functionality while Microsoft focuses on efficient operations and more wide-spread practical solutions and coalitions,  plus they target in different target audiences 
 In addition, negative earnings, which means other underlying company issues, is a recipe for disaster as all the ratios that include the earnings will be negative and thus, should not be considered for investing

We are assuming that the ratios are fair 
 In periods of market exuberance or gloom, the multiples are skewed and does not necessarily reflects the fundamentals of the company we are trying to value 
 In short, while DCF uses a lot of assumptions, it is based more on the fundamentals of a company whereas multiples valuation is more market based 
 For example, during a market turmoil like the subprime crisis in 2007/8, the entire stock market was badly hit and the valuations on stocks then would not have fully reflected the fundamentals of the company 
 A company that reported a loss may sway market participants to assign it a lower multiple that can be discounted to its fundamentals 
 When we we the DCF method to value a company that has just reported a loss, it allows us to look further into the future in assessing the firm's true strength and worth

Valuing an asset typically involves establishing the value that would be assigned to it by participants 
 The comparable approach assigns value to an asset by reference to the 
observed values of other assets with similar, but not necessarily 
identical, characteristics 
 The technique relies on the proposition that
 assets having similar characteristics, especially risks and cash flow 
prospects, will trade at similar prices because otherwise arbitrage 
profits would be possible 
 One key difference between the comparables approach and the DCF model is
 that comparables valuation does not explicitly spell out the economic 
agents’ expectations of future cash flows or discount rates 
 Instead, 
the expectations and discount rates are embedded in the observed prices 
of the comparable assets 
 For example, transaction prices of comparable 
houses can be thought of as discounted values of expected future rents 
(cash flows) that can be realised by an investor who purchases the 
house 
 Because being explicit about expectations and discount rates is 
not needed to perform a comparables valuation, the methodology is 
potentially simpler to implement, but it is generally less transparent 
regarding the underlying assumptions

   Thus, when the overall economy slowed down and millions of homeowners defaulted on their loans the whole system came to a halt

 If banks are left alone to determine who to lend to and who not to lend to; the credit market will be tight and not grow very fast - as in Japan

The investopedia formula is the WACC based on the CAPM model, so it is heavily based on market assumptions, and in some cases it may end up being quite subjective for example when used in certain countries (shallow markets), or when valuing private companies 
 By fortune there is this simpler accounting based WACC that at the end must be the most used in by the company management in their decision making, and it's just  a weight of each kind of  liability (accounts payable, bank borrowing, bonds.

I believe that this act was necessary as it ensured
the injection of credit into the U.S 
 Economy in order to stimulate spending,
thereby raising incomes and rendering them more adequate to support debt repayments,
reducing the need to sell assets in several markets, ergo raising asset values,
creating wealth, and making more people creditworthy 
 This would certainly not have
been feasible if the Federal Funds Rate was simply reduced as in that case,
banks would have still had a great deal of non-performing loans and toxic
derivatives in their balance sheet 
 Upon considering the fact that very large
debt repayments which were growing faster than income, thereby decreasing
spending and subsequently, income, creditworthiness therefore affecting borrowing
and the momentum of the growth of income, and asset values,  as a result the effective creation of credit
would have been a far-fetched dream for the U.S 
 Economy 
 However, the TARP tremendously
reduced the risk in the balance sheets of large financial institutions and upon
supplementing that with growth-friendly monetary policy, a triumphant economic
regulatory environment were created which put an emphasis on the facile
availability of credit 
 This was not only beneficial for the U.S 
 Economy, but
also for that of the global economy not just because of increased
globalization, but also the amplification of such an effect as a result of the
utmost interconnectedness of the global economy because of credit default
swaps, which are financial instruments that serve as insurance against
non-payment 
 Such an instrument was facilitated by the creation of an agreement
in which the lender agrees to pay premiums on the swap and if their client
defaults, the seller of the credit default swap agrees to pay the principal to
the lender 
 Therefore, credit default swaps were backed by the trust of the seller
to pay the principal to the lender in the case of a credit event auction 
 In
fact, the total value of credit default swaps in the market in the
pre-recession era was 20 times that of subprime mortgages and therefore, made
for the interconnectedness of balance sheets all over the world, so if one bank
failed, the effects would be felt throughout the world as that bank has
probably issued hundreds of credit default swaps 
 So, this bailout was not just
for the betterment of the U.S 
 Economy, but also that of the rest of the world.
Nevertheless, some state that this served as a source of bad incentives for
major financial institutions 
 Nothing could be further from the truth as it was
also supplemented with increased regulatory mandates such as the Dodd-Frank
Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act which mandated stricter
disclosure policies for such institutions and discouraged extensive
risk-taking 
 As a result, U.S 
 Bank balance sheets have since ballooned and
have much less leverage and risk than ever before, and healthy economic growth was
empowered as a result 
 Also, the mentality which many Wall Street executives
had at the before the crisis, manifesting itself in the form of incentive
trumping ethics almost every time, has since been eradicated as a result of
such acts 
 Some could even argue that the mandating of such reforms was far more
effective than the $3.4 trillion worth of QE in 2008, as it was not a driver of
economic growth with it being in the same range post and pre QE (1.5% to 2%),
gave incentives of corporations to buy back stock and not invest in large cash
flow projects which would create employment and raise income, thereby constituting
a wealth effect for investors, and was not a driver of wage growth 
 Therefore,
the mandating of the TARP and it being supplemented with stricter regulation
was very effective when inaugurated with decreased interest rates as it
efficiently and rapidly stimulated the U.S 
 Economy relative to that of other
economies with similar scales

When using the multiples-based valuation method, we assume that the comparable firms are within the same industry (same operating risk) and in similar stages of development (same expected growth rates) 
  When using the P/E ratio, we also assume comparable firms have similar financing structure 
 While it can be difficult to ascertain a lot of this information without knowledge of both companies,  the industry field, and a bit of additional research, the multiples-based valuation method should only be used in instances when this information is known 
 If you don't know whether a firm is truly comparable or not, you already know this will be a weak approach 
 Furthermore, the multiples-based valuation method assumes a fair value market comparison 
 However, markets do not often reflect a fair market value in the short term - stocks fluctuate and companies can be over or undervalued based on various factors 
 Short terms loses may not reflect long term gains

We assume that the prices of other companies are reasonable 
 Yet it could happen that an entire industry is overheated and overrated by investors such as prior to the burst of the dotcom bubble 
 Also nowadays when the interest rates worldwide are on very low levels and several major regions have introduced QE measures to boost economy, one is no longer sure whether stock prices really reflect the value of the companies or they are just high because money is cheap

The basic assumption is that the company's future earnings are comparable going to be close to what is projected, on average, for similar companies in the sector, as reflected by the appropriate multiple 
 This approach does not factor in crucial details such as company leadership, direct competition by another company or product superiority/inferiority 
 In addition, bubble economies, such as the dot-com bubble, will inflate the multiples across the whole market and thus skew valuation for all stocks in the bubble 
 In case of negative earnings, multiples are ill-defined and thus cannot be used 
 This also applies to start-ups, where no earnings have been reported because the product is still in development

What we are talking about here is simply moral hazard, or the lack therein of bank policies 
 Looked at logically, there is no incentive for banks to moderate or indeed change any part of their lending practices 
 However, lending was never the issue for the so-called Great Recession 
 In fact, the depression from which we are still recovering was a result of the lack of segmentation in the Retail and Investment banking arms 
 What does this mean 
 The Great Depression was caused by massive speculative investment mania by ordinary citizens being allowed to borrow on margin into a roaring bull market where underlying value was detached from price of stocks 
 This inevitably led to a bubble or massive proportions and a resulting crash 
 However, many banks and lenders were allowed to go to the wall 
 Whilst some commentators believe that this was the root cause of the impact and sharp decline in the stock market value, the recovery was also relatively quick lasting approximately 3 years from start to finish 
 By contrast, because no banks were allowed to fail other than Lehman Brothers which was used an example of the systemic failure that could occur if other investment banks were allowed to go bust, this allowed the banking leaders (and root cause of the overvaluation of the housing market) to petition for TARP funding from the US government to the tune of $700 million in the first instance and much more subsequently as described in the previous video 
 Essentially, the government with the aid of Hank Paulson to justify the massive bail out of private banks with public money 
 It is worth remembering that government does not have any money other than through borrowing (bond market) or tax receipts, i.e 
 The earnings of private citizens and to a lesser extent companies who tend to offshore their earnings in tax friendly jurisdictions 
 So this is what is meant by Moral Hazard 
 Nothing other than the inefficient Dodd-Frank bill has been put in place to prevent a repeat of the Great Recession in the next couple of years 
 However, the bust this time will be much greater a) because the original debt has not been cleared by allowing banks to go bust and b) because the banks now believe that however they choose to make money they will be back-stopped by the tax payer - privatizing the profits and socializing the losses 
 In contrast, the Glass-Steagall act was introduced at the end of the Great Depression to separate Investment and Retail banking arms thereby preventing excessive risk taking by the speculation activity of Investment banks from adversely affecting the 'real economy' i.e 
 Business lending and private debt creation 
 The last part of this act was repealed by Clinton in 1999 under massive lobbying from the larger banks and this allowed the creation of banking monoliths such as Citigroup (so-called 'Too Big to Fail' institutions)and also the creation of extremely exotic synthetic investment products such as CDO's, securitized mortgages, virtualized securitized mortgage backed securities underwritten by the ratings agencies who were at once employed and expected to be dispassionate about the risk involved in producing these products which no-one actually understood 
 The cross-selling and  mixing of these products by investment banks meant that no-one understood exactly what assets belonged to whom, leading to a loss of confidence and so-called Credit Crunch when banks refused to lend to each without exorbitant inter-bank lending rates 
 The Central banks were then called upon to act as the lender of last resort which in this instance was the correct approach as the actual situation at the end of 2008 was much more serious than that in 1929 
 This would have been an effective strategy only in so far as it allowed risky assets to be disposed of and bank balance sheets brought under control reducing the leverage from in some cases up to 40:1 down to more historically manageable levels, perhaps around 9:1 
 This unhappily has not happened, and the opportunity has been lost to achieve this aim. This means that the bank balance sheets are in poor shape as they were and consumers are likewise carrying huge burdens of debt 
 Growth levels have been weak because of this and in fact despite the lowest interest rates ever recorded, there is little appetite for more debt 
 Debt is linked to growth of consumer spending in the US which has a knock-on effect for exporting economies such as the Eurozone which typically does not have the same level of private consumption

The assumptions are that 1) there are observable/listed comparable companies in the market 2) the comparable companies should have similar operating business in nature to render a meaningful valuation 
 For instance, when UBER was born, it was hard to figure out its enterprise value using multiple-based methods as there were no practically "comparable" companies: the car calling/sharing business UBER created was an entirely blue-ocean market 
 And even though Alphabet and Apple are both categorized as tech companies, their business nature are quite different: Apple's earnings are primarily driven by selling hardwares (e.g 
 IPhone/iPad/Mac) whereas Google's income comes from advertising fees plus other internet services 
 So it would be reckless to simply derive Apple's share price by using Google's P/E multiples 
 3) the multiples correctly reflect the enterprise value 
 However, this is not the case when markets are having bubbles or experiencing crashes 
 The multiples tend to deviate dramatically from its fair value during these periods 
 (e.g 
 _domain_  bubble and its subsequent crash) 4) the multiple-based methods explicitly require that companies being valued have positive earnings 
 This is not the case for most (tech) start-ups or companies in early stages as they are essentially surviving/expanding by using investors money

There're few reasons why multiples method are risky: Benchmark difficulty-Finding the benchmark that in the same industry,has similar financial structure and at the same development stage is hard 
 Especially compares private equity firm to IPO company 
 Without benchmark :Emergence industries and pioneer corporation is hard to find the same competitor in the industry 
 Strategic Difference:Even the similar corporations can apply different strategic that drive to different resource allocation and market  strategy 
 Competition :The earlier IPO company can take advantage from the latter one 
 Thus earning and market share might be more poor than the earlier one, which results in different market valuation 
 For the negative earning estimation:Can use previous year earning for estimation 
 Or uses  the benchmarks P/E at the similar stage and previous year earning to estimate

Since multiples-based valuation methods use ratios, it is of tantamount importance to consider how these ratios are computed and based - the financial statements 
 Each company uses different accounting assumptions that are also acceptable and in accordance with the GAAP 
 For example, the depreciation method you are using is different to that of the comparable company; inventory valuation methods may also vary like FIFO, LIFO, and Weighted Average 
 These accounting assumptions would produce different accounting data and of course, would result to a different financial ratios that multiples-based valuation methods used

After seeing the videos on gold and formally learning how it can be used to hedge against fortuitous events, I think having gold as part of one's portfolio is an important insurance that a prudent investor should not under-estimate nor overlook 
 If I were to decide on how much of my portfolio should be invested in gold, I will probably invest in gold only at the optimal level, or the level where you balance the benefits of holding gold as a hedge vis-a-vis the cost of gold investments (both opportunity and carrying cost) 
   Although I acknowledge the difficulty of determining this optimal level due to the difficulty of predicting extreme events that have a negative impact on the performance of alternative investment options, I also believe that it is important to consider the concept of risk and return in making these decisions 
 The risk in this case is the happening of an extreme event that will have an adverse effect on non-gold investments, whereas the return is the interest and/or gain that one will earn when investing in traditional assets 
 In the end, I think there should be a balance, extreme events are highly unlikely (although not impossible) and the number of their occurrence are few and far in between, so might as well take some risk and rake the returns, anyway, in the event that black swans happen, at least the returns you earned during the good times will somehow offset the impact of the negative extreme events 
 In conclusion, I will put a small portion of my portfolio in gold investments as hedge but not too much as to forego the gains of holding other investments and/or assets

Multiple-based valuations also make assumptions 
 The methods must assume that many variables are acting as constants in their calculations 
 They can't take into accounts the unknowns, black swan events, and the like 
 So, when you begin to see signs of a bubble, some of the assumptions must be reassessed 
 Additionally, company value must be adjusted 
 During the 2000's, American politicians created a cash for clunkers deal to invigorate the auto market; however, it caused a decline some months later and actually had a negative impact on low income folks due the lack of availability of used cars and used car parts 
 The short term bump given to auto companies was followed by a decline and so using peak performance data would skew results 
 Likewise, we could find similar data for banks and home builders in the years preceding the subprime crisis 
 So, if the numbers are considerably off historical averages, it might yield inaccurate information and poor valuations

There are a number of assumption underlying the use of the multiples is that present flaws: first of all, the idea that the listed company is correctly priced 
 This might not be the case, in particular when a recent macroeconomic event makes all the shares of a specific market plunge 
 Then, it is worth to mention the idea is that there is a direct correlation between the actual results of the comparable company reflects somehow the future performance 
 Theoretically, the price of a share reflect the expectations of the stream of the future cash flows that the company will be able to produce 
 Even if two companies in the same industry are influenced by a large number of common, the companies will not perform equally 
 In addition, it is to prove that a company that achieved good results up to the last year will perform equally good in the coming ones 
 Another fact to consider, is that sometimes you cannot compute some specific multiples 
 For instance, there are a number of listed companies that despite a lot of activity does not post any earning or even margins like EBITDA 
 Thus, it would be meaningless to compute some multiples

 According to me we can use a new approach to calculate the fairness of the ratio based methods -    Taking  the average of the P/E ratio (or the other ratio in consideration) of the companies contributing (maximum to minimum) 66.6% in that particular business

 Then we should compare the ratio

One key issue that was not used in this question of the use of gold in portfolio construction and that was related to the time horizon of the investor 
 We have not used gold in our portfolios due to our long term hold strategy 
 We have found that by rebalancing during tops and bottoms we can reduce risks and enhance returns while staying fully invested during downturns in the markets 
 This was also true during the difficult 2008/2009 period 
 I have found that it is extremely difficult both intellectually and emotionally to predict significant downturns and reversals 
 Since this is our case if we were to hold gold it would have an opportunity cost to our portfolio

As we have seen, gold can serve as a hedge against extreme events that tend to hurt the performance of other assets (political tensions, stock market crashes, hyperinflation, 
 ) 
  An important characteristics of these events is that they are impossible (or very hard) to predict until it’s too late 
 So to hedge against these events, an investor would have to hold some gold at all time in his or her portfolio as an insurance, instead of waiting for the last moment when the price of gold is likely to have already shot up 
 On the other hand, we have also seen that holding gold entails an opportunity cost meaning that during periods where no extreme events take place, you miss the opportunity of making returns by investing in other financial assets (e.g 
 Stocks or bonds which are supposed to reward you over time for your invested capital) in addition to the possibility of seeing the price of gold decrease as the memories of past extreme events disappear from the minds of other investors who progressively liquidate their gold position 
 So, would you rather have a relatively large part of your portfolio invested in gold at all times as an insurance, or a relatively small part and stomach the impact that extreme events may have on traditional assets, with the conviction that these assets are ultimately the ones that will enhance your living standard because they are supposed to reward you for your invested capital

 Personally I dispute the generally accepted theory that the Fed had to rescue the existing banks 
 With the massive amount of money that was spent bailing out the existing banks, that had made terrible decisions, they could have established several entirely NEW banks with pristine balance sheets, and they could have purchased the bad loans books of the existing banks for say 30 cents on the dollar 
 This would have done two things; (1) people would not have lost their homes, as they would have simply changed the bank that they were making payments to, and (2) it would have purged the banking system of its debt burden, and if the old banks became insolvent, then they deserved that 
 Only the share holders and bond holders of the old banks would have lost money, not the general population

We assume that comparable companies are valued accurately 
 This assumption is subject to a number of variable factors, particularly recent earnings reports 
 A company's valuation may quickly become over- or under-inflated due to the emotions of investors following good or bad news 
 If using a company with a recent fluctuation in stock price for comparison, the valuation may be inaccurate 
 Another factor could be inflation of earnings by comparable companies 
 Fiat Chrysler, for instance, just reported that the company has inflated sales prices for the past three years on new cars 
 The valuation of the company is subject to change based on this information 
 If Fiat Chrysler was used as a comparable company to evaluate a comparable company, the valuation will be inaccurate
The comparable companies must have a price that correctly reflects their value

In our company we use DCF in almost all cases when valuating the operational business subsidiaries 
 Based on the strategic plan and the budgets a DCF is possible and according to my view the best way to find a company value or to defend your book value as shareholder 
 P/E ratios are the exception for valuating investments but used in case of start ups or early stage companies 
 There you have negative cash flows and DCF makes no sense 
 But P/E ratios should only be applied by companies of the same industry or sector at the same stage of development and with a similar financing structure 
 To find these data is not so easy and it can be quite misleading 
 Please have a look at the  _domain_  disaster at the beginning of 2000 where a many companies with negative cash flows were valued incredibly high until the whole thing collapsed

The most glaring risk when attempting to value a company based on market ratios is to believe that all enterprises within the same market have the same business behaviour 
 That is dangerous because it fails to take into account aspects that are unaccounted for and yet could unleash tremendous value, such as a dominant market position or promising R&D on future IP 
 It also fails to take into account discrepancies in investment cycles 
 Indeed, companies X and Y belonging to the same market might not invest the same amounts, at the same time, and for similar time-scales 
 Most importantly, especially in our age of "multidisciplinary corporations", multiples-based valuation method may not allow to capture the value a company might have or has the potential to reach, in other, often unsuspected, markets 
 There are plenty of instances to outline all the risks detailed above, but the most striking example to me is Amazon, Inc.  This company has built market dominance in e-commerce, that took years for investors to actually value 
 It also continuously lost money, so it's P/E ratio came inconsistently with market norms 
 Its investments as well as R&D expenditures, especially in cloud computing, were underestimated 
 And, it captured new markets such as indeed cloud computing but now retail, with the acquisition of Whole Foods 
 So Amazon has repeatedly come up as a company that was under- or overvalued using multiples-based valuation 
 PS: I'm also neglecting many variables such as management style, leadership strength, quality of early investors, level of transparency and audit purity, credit risk and so forth 
 But I'm closing down to the most obvious

To answer the undirbúning question "why not always use multiple-bases valuation methods?" We do so assuming all micro economical factors between the two companies are the same (I.e 
 Financial structure, growth stage and industry risks) but what we do not take into account are the Who What and How which might make one company more valuable than the other one which won't be reflected by the stock prices immediately 
 The assumption we make when we use ratios is that they are mutually competitive and will have similar performance in the market 
 A perfect example of when a multiple based valuation method would have been a bad idea is during the  _domain_  bubble 
 By comparing with similar companies would have lead to incorrect forecasts and ultimately overvaluation of a given company 
 If a company just reported a loss their P/E ratio may not reflect the actual valuation of the company for example if that company experiences seasonal sales/revenue boosts 
 Their P/E ration in Q2 might be quite high compared to Q4 where it will drop significantly due to earning reports

When using Price/Earnings ratio we assume the company's earnings for the comparable are consistent with past and future earnings and it does not take into consideration surges or major losses 
 One instance I would not feel comfortable using the Multiple based method is during the 2008 market recession 
 Many companies reported major losses hence the market did not reflect the price of a comparable private company

A critical assumption when using multiples is that the two companies would grow at the same rate, would have access to similar capital markets and consumers among other things 
 Looking at two fast food chains for example, if we use multiples to value them we assume that their management would perform similar 
 However, as in the recent case of Burger Kind, they decided to do a reverse-merger with a Canadian company which resulted in tax and other savings as well as access to other markets, something that a multiple would not reflect at that time 
 On the flip side McDonalds was performing particularly poorly in the previous few years (the last year was a turnaround) and if we used a multiple we would overvalue its stock when the intrinsic (company specific) factors would prove otherwise 
 In order to properly value the company a DCF model is necessary, though it may not tell the whole story for which we would need to "anchor" its value with alternative valuation techniques such as multiples

It can be Simplistic: A multiple is a distillation of a great deal of information into a single number or series of numbers 
 By combining many value drivers into a point estimate, multiples may make it difficult to disaggregate the effect of different drivers, such as growth, on value 
 The danger is that this encourages simplistic – and possibly erroneous – interpretation It's Static, a multiple represents a snapshot of where a firm is at a point in time, but fails to capture the dynamic and ever-evolving nature of business and competition 
 It can have Difficulties used to make comparisons of relative value 
 But comparing multiples is an exacting art form, because there are so many reasons that multiples can differ, not all of which relate to true differences in value 
 For example, different accounting policies can result in diverging multiples for otherwise identical operating businesses 
 The use of multiples only reveals patterns in relative values, not absolute values 
 If the peer group as a whole is incorrectly valued (such as may happen during a stock market "bubble") then the resulting multiples will also be misvalued

The answer should mostly reside on the characteristics of the numerous black swans that we want to take into account 
 First of all, you would want to make sure that the worst-case scenario which is impacting your portfolio as a whole, can be balanced by the potential gains the gold would make within such context 
 That's the actuarial, statistical approach 
 But that's not all. Gold can indeed act as a prominent hedge against multiple financial risks, yet it is far from alone 
 Frontier vehicles such as art or wine may also provide a respectable hedge under similar and perhaps wider-contexted environments and, therefore, limits the extent to which gold may take a share of an efficient portfolio 
 Furthermore, gold is so prominent in financial history that it confers it some disadvantages: the political risks 
 Indeed, nation states can consider gold reserves as strategic and part of their national security, therefore access to gold may be restricted, and governments may even seize gold assets for political motives 
 Last but not least, there are some black swan scenarios that themselves involve high risk for the value of gold itself 
 My favourite one is probably the advent of fin-tech and cryptocurrency 
 If a virtual-based asset class becomes a genuinely secure way to hedge against the same risks that gold is supposed to counter, then market psychology might finally consider gold as a mere commodity, like nickel, and therefore all of its financial appeals may just be replaced by the virtually-issued one. All of this taken into context makes it so that gold does not longer represent a fascinating hedge or any form of long-term insurance 
 I would, therefore, simply use it as another asset class like bonds, stocks, currencies and so forth 
 That is, with its risks and rewards, but no longer the same view that history regards it so

The main assumption of the multiples-based valuation method is that there is a logical resemblance between the ratios compared within companies of the same industry 
 For this to stand logically, then the companies that we compare our stock with must have approximately the same capital structure, returns on invested capital and expected growth rates 
 Also the P/E ratio is subject to distortions in differences of accounting rules-such as restructuring charges and write-offs- and capital structures between companies 
 So if the companies that we compare are of similar industry, similar volume and calculate their earnings in the same way the P/E ratio is indeed a good measure of valuation 
 However better measures of valuation for companies even with this criteria are enterprise-based ratios, which unlike the P/E ratio are independent of capital structures

Hi Mircea, In Question 9, there can be more than one correct answer 
 When we say: "When evaluating each of the following statements, assume all other variables were estimated correctly."  we mean that you should treat each statement as a separate question 
 For each statement, you should ask yourself: "What would be the impact of this mistake on my estimate of the stock price all other things equal" 
  We put this hint to avoid people getting mixed up with reasoning such as "if I overestimated the constant growth rate, what would be the impact of the WACC?" 
  In this example, you should ignore the WACC (and other variables) if you are trying to measure the impact of the overestimation of the constant growth rate on your estimate of the stock price

The general assumption when using ratios to value comparable companies is that the firms are in the same industry, at the same stage of development and have similar financing structures 
 Collectively, these factors add up to a large assumption on top of which there is the assumption that the earnings analysis is correct which may not always be the case particularly for overseas stocks where accounting conventions differ 
 Nevertheless, the ration most used for company valuations is the P/E ratio or a variant of it 
 In bull markets P/E ratios tend to be higher reflecting general market optimism and the the opposite in a bear market scenario 
 In a bubble the ratios tend to get way out of sync with reality which makes valuation increasingly challenging 
 For example, the dotcom era witnessed extreme valuations for companies with no earnings records 
 Companies like Amazon, Google, and E-Trade all had multiples over 100 without any significant earnings 
 Ultimately, some were arguably justified (Amazon) while others were not (e-Trade)

A couple of things are wrong with your statement 
 Personal checks, credit cards, and saving accounts are part of currency in circulation 
 Bank reserves, which is what increased under quantative easing are not. I'm sorry to be snarky here--that's why they're called reserves 
 People constantly refer to that as "money printing," it is not. Again, you don't have to take my word for it 
 Economist Lacy Hunt: ( link:   The evidence speaks for itself: the Fed cannot print money 
 The Fed does not have the authority or the mechanism to print money 
 They have not, they are not and they will not print money under present laws 
 It is a major oversimplification to say increasing the money supply leads to inflation 
 Under many circumstances--e.g 
 The money supply rose in the 1980s but inflation did not occur because of limited velocity This may be outside the scope of this course but the subject is interesting and important 
 The equation is MV=PY where M is money supply , V velocity, P prices, and Y output 
 If V does not go up, or if Y increases then the increased money supply does not lead to inflation 
 I realize this is a beginning course but the professor should have avoided a misleading, overgeneralized statement

“Public” and “Private”   Dear
all:   Since
there may be a large number of Chinese students attending this course,
clarifications of the terms “public” and “private” are called-for, in view of
the specific political and economic systems under which we’ve been living 
 In
English, and especially in English in the financial and economic fields, “public”,
as in “a public company”, means “publically listed on the stock market”; in
terms of financing, “public” placement means that the investor takes a more
widespread approach to financing or fund-raising; and “private” placement does
not mean that he or she just takes care of their own money or property 
 A “private”
investor, as the term is used in Module 1, also includes someone who serves as
a financial intermediary, simply not on such a grand scale, and maybe just
raising money among friends and relatives 
 Additionally,
“socialism” in the true sense of the word, means a country with a small
government and a large society 
 Since China’s civil society was abolished for
decades, we tend to fancy that socialism means the government takes care of
everything for you, just short of changing your diapers 
 The Western conception
is much more healthy and should be a model for us to follow 
 Best,
YHY

 Gold is an insurance policy and as such requires payment (opportunity cost) 
  The benefit is a potentially more stable portfolio during times of uncertainty (inflation, political risk, etc.), the cost is the loss of potential returns from the funds being allocated to higher income generating instruments

Multiples-based valuation methods assume that other comparable companies are correctly valued

 For instance if we are valuing Banking stocks .i.e 
 JPM, JPMorgan and take a comparable PE ratio or even net tangible book value as comparison yardsticks of BAC (bank of america) or even C (citigroup) we would not get an accurate valuation for JPM as the events that impacted all 3 banks during the financial crisis (2007-8) are very different and they all came out of it impacted differently 
 BAC and C get almost wiped out if it was not for the bail out, JPM on the other hand had excellent management and a rock solid balance sheet which allowed them to weather the crisis with less turmoil than either C  or BAC. The assumption that the companies are are similar enough that their relative price divided by their earnings should be similar, when realistically because a company is in the same industry does not mean that they produce the exact same competing product 
 A good example of this is trying to use the multiples-based valuation of auto makers (Ford, GM, VW, etc.) to value a company like Tesla 
 While these companies are the most similar companies in terms of industry and product to Tesla, as this value comparison assumes that Telsa has a similar business model to that of other automakers, when in reality, Tesla's business model is drastically different and could affect their future earnings much differently than the other automaker

 A valuation multiple is simply an expression of market value of an asset relative to a key statistic that is assumed to relate to that value 
 You would not have felt comfortable using multiple-based valuation methods to value companies when that statistic – whether earnings, cash flow or some other measure – does not bear a logical relationship to the market value observed, when it is not seen as the driver of that market value 
 A multiple is a distillation of a great deal of information into a single number or series of numbers 
 By combining many value drivers into a point estimate, multiples may make it difficult to disaggregate the effect of different drivers, such as growth, on value 
 The danger is that this encourages simplistic – and possibly erroneous – interpretation 
 A multiple represents a snapshot of where a firm is at a point in time, but fails to capture the dynamic and ever-evolving nature of business and competition 
 Multiples are primarily used to make comparisons of relative value 
 But comparing multiples is an exacting art form, because there are so many reasons that multiples can differ, not all of which relate to true differences in value 
 For example, different accounting policies can result in diverging multiples for otherwise identical operating businesses 
 The use of multiples only reveals patterns in relative values, not absolute values such as those obtained from discounted cash flow valuations 
 If the peer group as a whole is incorrectly valued (such as may happen during a stock market "bubble") then the resulting multiples will also be misvalued 
 Multiples are based on historic data or near-term forecasts 
 Valuations based on multiples will therefore fail to capture differences in projected performance over the longer term, and will have difficulty correctly valuing cyclical industries unless somewhat subjective normalization adjustments are made 
 Companies with losses (negative earnings) or no profit have an undefined P/E ratio (usually shown as "not applicable" or "N/A"); sometimes, however, a negative P/E ratio may be shown 
 There are multiple versions of the P/E ratio, depending on whether earnings are projected or realized, and the type of earnings 
 Companies with losses (negative earnings) or no profit have an undefined P/E ratio (usually shown as "not applicable" or "N/A"); sometimes, however, a negative P/E ratio may be shown

Just before, the US governement had adopted a different approach, by not bailing out Lehman Brothers, which went bankrupt 
 From a moral standpoint, and maybe educational one, it was a more satisfactory policy by letting the banks pay a high price for their mistakes 
 But the consequences to the rest of the economy were immediate  and very negative 
 With TARP, the US government and the US Central Bank did what was needed for the economy to keep on going 
 Had they not done it, the financial problems would have continued and contaminated the real economy: eg the fact that banks could not refinance their operations would lead them to stop lending for the daily operation of businesses, and the economy would come to a halt 
 This is what happened during the great depression in 1929 
 Ben Bernanke was actually a specialist of that era and avoided those drastic consequences 
 It is not useful to think that behaviour of banks can be educated like human beings 
 Faced with a small risk of losing everything, and a high chance of making a lot of money, there will always be companies that will go for the risky way even if there is a risk for the whole system 
 Knowing that they will or will not be saved at the end does not make much difference for them in their decision making process, in my view 
 Solution comes from a regulation that can prevent most (at least some) of the problems in advance

While using ratios to value other comparable comapnies , we exclude the possibility of a technological breakthrough that may disrupt the current trends in the industry 
 Also, if the stock price of one of the companies is overvalued due to some speculation, we are taking not so right premise for our valuation of a company in the same industry 
 An instance, where it may not have been prudent to use multiple based valuation method is in case mobile phones market, while looking at the stock price of other mobile phones manufacturers like samsung, if we would have bought the stock of Nokia, before the development of smart phones 
 It would have been catastrophic

We are assuming that the ratio we are using is correct 
 Even if we get a study group of very similar companies, sometimes we get information that deviates from the norm 
 And the reason for that may be multiple, from the welfare of the company to market influences 
 Even if we ignore, or if these deviations are non existent, when we get a ratio of these comparable companies and use it on the company we are studying on investing, it may give a wrong message of the company 
 Since there is no equal person, there is no equal companies 
 And if not used correctly, these ratios may give a wrong ideia of the price of the company, for better of for worse 
 In the case of a company reporting a loss, I find that we should avoid using the ratio without studying the tendency of the company and the market, since there are companies that suffer more than others with market tendencies, and only when we understand the reason of said loss, we can use the ratios

There are several caveats to consider when applying relative valuation:
 - Relative valuation does not involve any assumption on the evolution of fundamentala (growth, margin, risk,etc) - Firms in different countries could be subject to different accounting regimes
 - Some measures required to compute multiples (such as EBITDA) are not uniquely defined, resulting in differences in how firms calculate them
 - If the multiple is based on market values (such as P/E), valuation could reflect market trend more than the effective value of the firm
 - Identification of "comparable" firms is extremely subjective
 - Multiples on actual values do not factor in any recent development for the firm

Why not always use multiple-based
valuation method?:Because this
valuation method relies heavily on picking comparable firms, it is subject to
the biases of the analyst making the valuation of a firm 
 An analyst may pick
“comparable” firms to confirm his bias – and the determination of what makes
firms comparable to one another is by itself subjective 
 It is also
built on the possibility that the entire sector itself, or the comparable firms
themselves, are undervalued or overvalued, and this dependence or reliance on
relative values may be problematic – it is only backed by the faith or
assumption that the market has done a good job in pricing the firms 
 There are
several instances in history that prove this point: the events that led to the
tech bubble for example 
 Furthermore,
it’s also possible for firms to have a negative P/E ratio, especially for those
that are losing money

Multiples-based valuations are suitable for obtaining an instantaneous snapshot of a company's financial position relative to comparable companies for a given earnings period 
 They do not provide any information on the future of various companies or industries 
 Multiples based valuation can distort the investment picture in a variety of cases where a shock event causes the regulatory environment, macroeconomic condition or marketplace competition to change suddenly 
 Multiples-based valuation provides a picture only of what just happened, but it is a logical fallacy to assume that past events are accurate predictors of future events

 This makes no comparable companies to exist from where comparisons can be drawn 
 Companies that just reported a loss can be judged according to whether it was a unique of a condition like a Black Swan to occur or whether this type of performance has its ground in the past as well
