From a pure
economical perspective the U.S 
 Government had simply no choice than the bailout 
 We all know
what happened with Lehman’s Brother and how this impacted private, public,
institutional investors across the globe 
 Even the tiniest German Sparkasse had
investments in Lehman’ Brother – all gone 
 Nobody had a clue what the impacts/consequences could be when other global financial institutions would default or wouldn’t
be able to ‘assist’ the global economic system 
 Below,
there are two shortened sub-chapters copied from my Diploma thesis (all footnotes were
removed to facilitate legibility) 
  I researched the impact of global financial
flows on the real estate sector in transforming countries 
 The thesis was
submitted in January 2012 at the Technical University Berlin 
 These
sub-chapters emphasis how the global financial system and real estate sector is interrelated and
embedded in the global political and economic landscape 
 Simply speaking,
the bailout was absolutely necessary to avoid a collapse of the entire system.
In this context, I tend to ignore any moral or business ethical discussion on
this question 
 The finance
sector  The
formation of the global financial system is the result of national deregulation
of capital controls, liberalization of capital flows across the globe and the
evolvement of new technologies, telecommunication and information based
economy 
 Since
the 1980s, the global economy has been experiencing a profound shift from an
industrial related one to a more financially integrated one. Between 1980 and
1995, global capital flows have fluctuated between two and six percent of world
gross domestic product (GDP) 
  This sharply grew to 14.8 percent of world GDP by
2006 
 Moreover,
annual global capital flows tripled between 1995 and 2006 to a total US$7.2
trillion 
 The rapid transformation of the financial sector to a key driver in
globalization can basically be traced back to three crucial changes during the
1960s and 1970s 
 Firstly,
the emergence of a Eurocurrency market in the 1960s, in which the first
international financial system was developed in which banks were dealing in
foreign currency 
 The system supported cross-border transactions and avoided
domestic regulations for Transnational Corporations (TNCs) due the fact they
deposited their surplus funds in foreign currency, thus increasing the need for
financial service activity 
 This has slowly softened under the Bretton Woods
System (BWS), which was established to return security to national economic
markets after years of high insecurity and low worldwide trade and investment
during the two World Wars 
 The
BWS collapsed in 1973 when President Nixon questioned the pegging of the dollar
to the gold reserves 
 Secondly, declining international confidence in the US
dollar established a system where currency exchange rates were determined by
their value on the global market 
 This established a foreign currency trading
market, which is the largest financial market in the world 
 Currencies can be
simultaneously traded in a 24-hours market completely electronically.
Therefore, thirdly, new technological innovations became a catalyst in the
emergence of the huge electronic financial transactions that have contributed
to the staggering evolution of the financial industry 
 The annual turnover in
foreign exchange was US$17.5 trillion in 1979, increasing to a daily level of
US$3.5 trillion or US$1,277.5 trillion annually in 2007 
 One
additional aspect was crucial in the globalization process and rise of the
financial sector 
 When the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC)
quadrupled the price of oil, most banks were faced by a dramatic surplus of
capital flows 
 Moreover, nations became more dependent on banking institutions
when OPEC members decided to channel the majority of their earnings ―through
the transnational banks 
 Within four years, between 1976 and 1980, the major
international banks experienced a staggering increase of 95 percent in their
aggregated assets 
 The capital accumulation of international banks also made
them increasingly become lending institutions to countries, which made these
countries increasingly dependent on these financial institutions - a key reason
for growing national financial deregulation 
 Facilitated
by global improvements in communication infrastructure and deregulation of
domestic financial markets, securitization of debts into marketable instruments
contributed to competition and vast expansion of the financial market 
 Banks
securitized formerly illiquid ‘assets‘, such as a mortgage loans into ‘new‘
financial products, which could be traded on the stock market 
 TNCs increased
capitalization by issuing equities 
 Additionally, nation states participated in
the financial market by issuing bonds to increase liquidity for themselves.
Another ‘innovative‘ financial product concerns the emergence of a secondary
mortgage market in the United States (U.S.) 
  Formerly illiquid debts became
transformed into liquid and tradable mortgage-backed securities that were
traded on the stock exchange 
 In particular with domestic financial
liberalization in the early 1990s, individuals and institutional investors
significantly contributed to an internationalization of financial market
activities by the purchase of equities, shares and bonds 
 The volume of
international equity issued in 1986 was at US$32 billion 
 In 1999 it rose to
the staggering amount of US$28 trillion 
 Real estate
development and globalization  The
transformation of the urban built environment reflects the global-local
interplay of globalisation forces 
 [ 
 ] 
  The real estate sector is also
an investment form, which boosts through speculation the artificial production
of the building stock in globalising cities 
 There
are three main developments, which have contributed to the emergence of a
global real estate market 
 First,
the global economy‘s shift towards banking and producer service activities
dramatically increased the demand for offices 
 [ 
 ] 
  Since the 1980s, that has led to the construction of
millions of sq m of new office space 
 ―The rapid building of one high-rise office
complex after another has transformed cities all across the world 
 Secondly,
there was an internationalisation of the office market by its developers, users
and owners 
 [ 
 ] 
  Increasing prices and growing demand for
office development produced record profits and attracted domestic and foreign
investors 
 Panreiter emphasises that major cities, in particular those that
have dynamic developments in advanced producer services, also correspond high
on cross-border real estate investment 
 Part of these increasing cross-border
real estate transactions are based on the fact that the financial sector are
users and buyers of the commercial properties 
 [ 
 ] 
   Understanding
that real estate development is a very capital-intensive economic sector, real
estate construction provided an ideal investment asset for the financial
industry 
 Real estate can act as securities and collateral for bank lending 
 In
fact, this shows that office markets in globalising cities are linked in an
international real estate and capital market 
 [ 
 ] 
   Thirdly,
new types of institutional investment by the end of the 1970s in form of
pension funds and insurance companies increased global real estate activities.
Considerable growth rates in the service sector, which promised constantly
increasing profits and the search for new long-term investment opportunities,
were major driving forces of institutional expansion 
 [ 
 ] 
  A
key aspect for the emergence of a global real estate market is the financial
liberalisation [ 
 ] 
  In
particular, the securitisation of former fixed real estate assets into stocks
and securities through real estate investment trusts (REITs) increased
liquidity, transparency and capital volume for national and international
property development 
 [ 
 ] 
  Predominantly
the securitisation of real estate from a fixed asset into a liquid and tradable
commodity enhanced global real estate market activities 
 A study by Jones Lang
LaSalle in 2008 showed that the volume in direct commercial property investment
has more than doubled from US$354 billion in 2003 to US$759 billion in 2007.
Cross-border transactions have been also constantly growing 
 In 2003, worldwide
cross-border commercial property transaction accounted for US$90 billion 
 That
volume grew to a staggering amount of US$353 billion in 2007 
 The promising
years of economic development between 2000 and 2007 also provided Asia-Pacific
with impressive economic growth rates 
 Cross-border transactions on commercial
property accounted for 32 percent in 2006, and rapidly grew one year later to a
remarkable 47 percent of all commercial property transactions in the region 
 [ 
 ] 
  Other
factors also increased real estate activities and their globalization 
 The
global expansion of TNCs increased not just the demand for commercial real
estate, but also the demand for residential property development, driven by a
growing mobile expatriate population worldwide 
 The number of worldwide
migrants almost doubled from 136 million in 1990 to 210 million in 2010 
 Stimulating
urban growth through housing and office construction has also successfully
impacted countries economic development by understanding how other supporting
services such as financing; architecture, consultancy, management and material
production are involved in real estate production 
 [ 
 ]

Hi all, Perhaps I can help with some extra information: When calculating the value of a company (i.e 
 What a fair price would be for it), there are different methods to estimate the value of that company 
 There are two primary methods presented in this course so far: DCF and Multiples 
 First method, multiples: now, as you may know, multiples are based on the idea that you can compare two companies and base a valuation of off that 
 But we're talking primarily about DCF and Terminal Value 
 The idea behind valueing the company using a DCF is that you take the company's future Fcf's (which are then discounted for the time value of money: inflation) 
  Generally, you will do a DCF by taking 4 to 7 years of future cash flows 
 Remember that enterprise value is calculated as follows (also see lectures and slides): V0 = ( FCF1 / ( 1 + Rwacc )) + ( FCF2  / (( 1 + Rwacc ) ^2 ) +  ( FCFn  + Vn / (( 1 + Rwacc ) ^ n )  What does this mean 
 It means that we calculate firm value by taking all free cash flows, discount them over the years, and then sum then 
 However, we only do the free cash flows for a couple of years (e.g 
 4-7 years), that is why we take the terminal value for the remaining years (assuming the company keeps on functioning, continuing) 
   Let us assume that Company A has the following FcF: 2015: 1 million FCF And we believe that this will keep growing by 5% each year 
 Then the result for a simple analysis would be (rounded _smiley_  2016: 1.05 mil 2017:  1.1 mil 2018:  1.16 mil 2019:  1.22 mil However, we also need to discount these cash flows 
 Let us assume the discount rate is 9% 
  That would mean the relevant FcFs would be: (The FcF / ( Discount rate ^ years ) ) 2016:  0.96 mil  (1.05 million / ( 1.09 ^ 1 ) ) 2017:  0.93 mil ( 1.1 million / ( 1.09 ^ 2) 2018:  0.90 mil ( 1.16 million / ( 1.09 ^ 3) 2019: 0.86 mil ( 1.22 million / ( 1.09 ^ 4) That is a total of: 3.65 million 
 Note:    But, we also need to calculate the terminal value 
 The formula for the terminal value is as follows:  Vn = ( ( 1 + Gfcf ) / ( Rwacc - Gfcf ) ) x FcFn This means that for your terminal value you divide your growth factor (5% in my case, so 1.05) by your discount rate minus your growth factor (so in my case 9 %- 5% = 0.04) 
  In our case this is:   1.05/0.04 = 26.25 
 And then you apply that number times the cash flow of the last year 
 That means, 0.86 million x 26.25 = 22.6 million  Total value:  3.65 mil + 22.6 mil = 26.25 mil  Note: I hope I made no mistakes 
 It may be wise to figure out what discount rates are, free cash flows, etc. I hope this helped, let me know if you have questions

On Sept 
 8, 2008, the U.S 
 Treasury seized control of mortgage giants Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac and pledged a $200 billion cash injection to help the companies cope with mortgage default losses 
 About a week later the government bailed out American International Group Inc., or AIG, with $85 billion 
 The Fed refused to save Lehman Brothers and the company was forced to file for bankruptcy

 As the crisis hit the global market, the credit freeze spread 
 The Treasury and the Federal Reserve began working on a $700 billion bailout plan 
 The US President signed the bailout plan into law Oct. 3 
 Weeks later, on Oct. 29, the Fed cut the key interest rate to 1% 
    What was expected   The government claimed the bailout was necessary to provide stability in the economy and prevent disruption in the financial system 
 The interest rate cut aimed to revive the economy, help free up credit and make loans cheaper to consumers and businesses 
 What happened   The financial markets remained in turmoil for several months 
 Credit remains tight to this day, although it loosened significantly compared to when lending nearly came to a halt during the collapse period 
 Mortgage rates fell significantly after the interest rate cut and amid expectations that the Fed would start buying mortgage-backed securities

Hi Mahmoud, Thank you for you interest and enjoyment of the course 
 You bring up a good question about leverage and borrowing costs 
 In regards to the interest rate on amounts you borrow, the example given by the instructor assumes no borrowing costs, however in the real world you do pay interest on capital 
 So, you are right that your returns would be decreased depending on the interest paid 
 These costs could be substantial, but as a proportion of total capital invested, might be a few percentage points or less 
 2 
 In regards to leverage in the example: even though you pay back the $100 you borrowed, you still have made $20 profit on your initial $100 investment which is 20% 
  Compared to not having leverage you would have made $10 on $100, which is 10% 
  Furthermore, in some financial markets and (more so for hedge funds), you can get leverage that is more than 2:1 
 For example you might get 20:1 or 100:1 
 This is where leverage takes on greater risk and reward 
 With 20:1 leverage your $100 now controls $2000 and making 10% of $2000 = $200 or $200 profit 
 In this example, you made $200 profit on a $100 investment with leverage and would have only made $10 without 
 As the instructor mentions, leverage can also amplify your losses 
 Hence, leverage-related financial crises

You need  knowledge (education) and experience to know which information is important to enable you to develop an opinion on what constitutes over-valued and under-valued 
 Annual reports and the Financial Times are old news that others have already acted upon 
 There isn't a lone number in an annual report or column in the FT or WSJ  that can tell you if a stock is over-valued or under-valued 
 You also need a lot of capital to be able to spread your risks among many different securities 
 The instructor uses somewhat extreme examples in which a stock goes from $100 to $50 
 That won't happen often 
 There are many things taught in this course that a small investor won't have the resources, time, or ability to act on 
 But, that doesn't mean that you can't be a successful investor 
 Most mutual fund managers beat the S&P 500 after their costs 
 You can closely match the return of the S&P500 (or other indexes) very cheaply 
 If you want to know a bit about how Warren Buffett and Charlie Munger value companies, the Berkshire Hathaway annual reports contain Buffett's annual letter to shareholders which offers investing wisdom

  Therefore in this scenario, you can add the percentages and calculate the average return

Hi all, Perhaps I can help with some extra information: When calculating the value of a company (i.e 
 What a fair price would be for it), there are different methods to estimate the value of that company 
 There are two primary methods presented in this course so far: DCF and Multiples 
 First method, multiples: now, as you may know, multiples are based on the idea that you can compare two companies and base a valuation of off that 
 But we're talking primarily about DCF and Terminal Value 
 The idea behind valueing the company using a DCF is that you take the company's future Fcf's (which are then discounted for the time value of money: inflation) 
  Generally, you will do a DCF by taking 4 to 7 years of future cash flows 
 Remember that enterprise value is calculated as follows (also see lectures and slides): V0 = ( FCF1 / ( 1 + Rwacc )) + ( FCF2  / (( 1 + Rwacc ) ^2 ) +  ( FCFn  + Vn / (( 1 + Rwacc ) ^ n )  What does this mean 
 It means that we calculate firm value by taking all free cash flows, discount them over the years, and then sum then 
 However, we only do the free cash flows for a couple of years (e.g 
 4-7 years), that is why we take the terminal value for the remaining years (assuming the company keeps on functioning, continuing) 
   Let us assume that Company A has the following FcF: 2015: 1 million FCF And we believe that this will keep growing by 5% each year 
 Then the result for a simple analysis would be (rounded _smiley_  2016: 1.05 mil 2017:  1.1 mil 2018:  1.16 mil 2019:  1.22 mil However, we also need to discount these cash flows 
 Let us assume the discount rate is 9% 
  That would mean the relevant FcFs would be: (The FcF / ( Discount rate ^ years ) ) 2016:  0.96 mil  (1.05 million / ( 1.09 ^ 1 ) ) 2017:  0.93 mil ( 1.1 million / ( 1.09 ^ 2) 2018:  0.90 mil ( 1.16 million / ( 1.09 ^ 3) 2019: 0.86 mil ( 1.22 million / ( 1.09 ^ 4) That is a total of: 3.65 million 
 Note:    But, we also need to calculate the terminal value 
 The formula for the terminal value is as follows:  Vn = ( ( 1 + Gfcf ) / ( Rwacc - Gfcf ) ) x FcFn This means that for your terminal value you divide your growth factor (5% in my case, so 1.05) by your discount rate minus your growth factor (so in my case 9 %- 5% = 0.04) 
  In our case this is:   1.05/0.04 = 26.25 
 And then you apply that number times the cash flow of the last year 
 That means, 0.86 million x 26.25 = 22.6 million  Total value:  3.65 mil + 22.6 mil = 26.25 mil  Note: I hope I made no mistakes 
 It may be wise to figure out what discount rates are, free cash flows, etc. I hope this helped, let me know if you have questions

The purpose of duration: The most important metric to mesure the price sensitivity  of a bond due to interest rates variation over the years 
 What are we measruing: The equilibrium point in time, of the  NPVs of all the cash flows 
 It means that the sum of present value of the cash flows prior to the duration point is equal the sum of present values of cash flows after the duration point 
 That part is merely technical 
 Why is it important 
 Once you buy a bond, it can be translated to a cash flow scheme, therefore you can measure the value of that bond 
 You measure that value using a given interest rate 
 (which will be the same during all the years until the maturity) 
  So, it's important to know that the value of your bond will never change 
 The amount of money that you will recieve in each coupon and the principal will never change 
 But what about it's value in the market, in other words, what about it's price 
 Let's assume that yesteray you bought a government bond with the following conditions:   Price: $1000    Interest rate: 10%   Maturity: 10 years 
 Coupons issued at the end of each year 
 Then, today the government raised the interest rate from 10% to 20% 
  Obiviously, the same $1000 is going to be much more proftable now, right 
 And also today, you need some money and decided to sell the bond you bought yesterday 
 Nobody is going to buy it for $1000, they prefer buy direct from the government 
 So, for how much are you going to sell 
 You can make that calculation very easily using the duration metric, like we saw on the video

Hi Ravi, In the formula, "r" is the (current) yield to maturity of your bond 
 When we say that "r" increases from 10% to 12%, we mean that there are now bonds in circulation (from the same issuer as yours, the same time to maturity and face value) with a yield to maturity of 12% instead of 10% (i.e 
 With a higher coupon rate than yours) 
   The formula we see in this video and which uses duration gives you an approximation of the drop in the price of your bond now that these new bonds came into existence 
 Indeed and as we have seen in the previous video, the price of your bond must drop to remain attractive in comparison with the new bonds now available to investors 
 I hope this clears things up 
 Best regards, Jonas

For example, if a company uses a P/E  ratio, and we suppose that the profit earnings are, lets say 100 in 2016, while the marketcap of that company is 3000 
 That means that the P/E ratio is 30 
 THis is quite high but consider the following: the company is growing super fast, and in 2017, we expect profit to be 300, with the same marketcap , 3000 
 This means that the P/E ratio in 2017 is only 10 
 The P/E ratio has been lower in one year due to its earnings are increasing (which means that it is cheaper) 
  This means that a P/E only teaches you something about the current situation (2016 in this example), it doesn't consider growth in the future and that's why it's not a good measure on its own

You always want to include the effects of dividends, stock splits, other distributions and corporate actions in your analysis,  so you can calculate your total return 
 If you use the adjusted close prices available from yahoo, it will take into account all dividends and stock splits 
 If you use just price data, your returns will look much worse than they are.  If you look at IBM, for example, the price on 1-2-1962 was $572 share 
 Today IBM's stock price is $121.04 
 Using only price data, it would appear that you have lost $472/share over the last 54 years 
 But there has been 54 years of dividend payments and 6 or 7 stock splits 
 If my quick calculations are correct, you'd now have 60 shares of IBM for each share purchased in 1962 
 You would also have 54 years of dividend payments 
 On June 6th, 2014 Apple's share price was $645.57 
 On Monday, June 9th, 2014, the share price was $93.70 
 Apple didn't just lose $551/share over the weekend 
 They had a 7:1 stock split 
 You would now own 7 shares of Apple for each one you had previously 
 Using only price data, it would appear you lost a horrible amount of money, but the effect of a stock split is that you neither gain nor lose any money 
 You simply have more shares at a lower price

Let me answer to this question with an example 
 Let's say you are a Greek citizen in 2016 
 You have a portfolio of investments which includes Greek gov bonds, Greek stocks and Euros in cash (Euro is the nominal currency of Greece) 
  Should you have gold in your portfolio 
 The answer is a big YES because all the reasons to have gold hold in Greece today at the same time 
 (1) The stock market has crashed (the index has collapsed due to the recapitalization of the banks 
 (2) The bonds have significantly high credit risk despite the controlled "delaultability" 
  Bonds are not safer than stocks and the risk premiums are really high 
 (3) Holding real estate has not negative correlation to the rest of the economy 
 The prices of the assets have fallen due to the tax policy on real estate assets, and stagnated 
 (4) Holding cash is less risky, but also risky 
 It brings no returns to euro holders 
 The risk-free rate (the interbank policy rate like the fed-fund) is near to minus, and the quantitative easing expanded by the ECB (in relation to the return to normality by the FED, makes the euro weaker 
 (5) There is also very low opportunity cost 
 In a stagnated market which was highly leveraged in the previews period of the business cycle, the process of de-leveraging is very slow 
 This means that the investment opportunities ahaid in time (at least in the mid-term) have disappeared 
 This reduces the opportunity cost of holding gold in the mid-term 
 (6) Last but not least, the political uncertainty in the Greek Government, the unstable relationship with the EU and the extra costs that the immigration crisis impose to the Greek budget, increases the political tension, the uncertainty over the prospect of political stability as well as the negative expectations of the future deficits of Greece, which rises the possibility for further tax burdens 
 (7) Having the previous six paragraphs in my mind, I wonder if there are also white swans, because all the swans I have seen so far are. 
  black!

Alright I can guess  what your confusion is, The $9000 M there you are using represents the value of the firm that is enterprise value Vo and the terminal value is Vn which is calculated ((1+0.02)/(0.12-0.02))*407 Gfcf=2%, rWACC=12%, FCFn=407 which is the last of the free cash flows as similar to the question just to make you clear Now once the terminal value Vn is calculated we now tend to calculate the value of the firm/Enterprise value which is Vo Vo = FCF1/1.12+FCF2/1.12^2+(FCF3+Vn)/1.12^3 FCF3 being 407 in this case the last forecasted future cash flow freely available to investor of both debt and equity   Note: In order to Use the DCF method we must be able to forecast free cash flows to a horizon of 4-7 years

Hi Scott, Thanks for asking this important question 
 
When the stock market goes up one day, and 
then goes down for the next five, then up again, and then down again, 
that’s what you call stock market volatility 
 


Volatility is measured by the Chicago Board of Options Exchange (CBOE), 
primarily through the CBOE Volatility Index (VIX) and, to a lesser 
extent, the CBOE Nasdaq Volatility Index (VXN) for technology stocks 
 
The VIX tracks the speed of stocks’ price movements in the S&P 100; 
the VXN tracks it in Nasdaq 100 stocks 
 Both indices take a weighted 
average of the estimated volatility of eight stocks on a particular 
index 
 Both are calculated every 60 seconds over the CBOE’s trading day,
 which means it records a great deal of fluctuation 
 



Seasoned traders who monitor the markets closely usually buy stocks and 
index options when the VIX is high 
 When the VIX is low, it usually 
indicates that investors believe the market will head higher 
 This, in 
turn, can trigger a market selloff, as speculators try to unload their 
holdings at premium prices.



Bearish types argue, however, that any value to the VIX’s past behavior 
ended on September 11 
 They say the market is up against too many 
things, including the economy, wary investors, and ongoing fear of 
terrorist attacks 
 Others blame volatility on 24/7 financial news on 
cable and the Internet, since people can watch the market move in front 
of their eyes.

 Hope this helps 
 Thanks, Chaturaka

In the lecture, he describes two scenarios for a 1000 dollar portfolio 
 One where you own 100 of a stock and the other where you short 100.  I understand the basic point: when you lose on a long bet, you own less of the stock, when you lose on a short bet you own more 
 This seems obvious by the very nature of the bets 
 However, what I am having trouble with is how he determines what portion of your portfolio the short bet actually is 
 What I am wondering is the net value of a short is zero initially:  you borrow 100 for a stock (-100), and immediately sell it (+100) and place the money with the bank as collateral so net impact to your investments is zero 
 This assumes you are one of the lucky few that the bank would actally do this for!  So for a portfolio of 1000 dollars, he seemed to be calculating that this net zero made up 10% 
   And he only put out 900 to make up the portfolio 
 In the other case, he had to invest 1000 
 So the example seems like comparing apples to oranges in some sense 
 When I initially answered the question, I stated that the relative position in the first portfolio decreased by assuming that we made 8.88% on the 900 (+80)  portion, and lost 80% on the 100 (-80) for a end value of 980+20 = 1000 with the 10% decreasing to 2% 
   For the second one it is not so straight forward if you think about it 
 We invested 1000 in the first portfolio (I assume real cash) in the second we only put 900 real cash, and have a 100 loan for the short 
 If the short increases by 20% and our 900 investment increases by 2.22% (20 dollars) then we can take the 20 dollars and pay for the margin call and still have net value of 1000 (although total value of 1020) 
   In this case, one could consider that the net outlay for the short is still 100 and for the other part is 900 - so the relative portions do not change 
 Or you could consider the total value of 1020 and compare to 120 which gives an 11.7% increase 
 I'm sure he did not mean for us to think this hard about it - but a "real world" apples to apples comparison would have been more useful in my opinion 
 And this leaves me with the question - how do you compute the actual value of a short in your portfolio

Owning a small percentage of gold (10%) is not going to provide enough "insurance" to a portfolio to rebuild losses in the other 90% 
  In 2008, a portfolio containing 10-20% gold still experienced huge losses 
 In 2008, SPY (S&P 500) lost almost 37%, GLD (Gold) gained 5% 
  In 2009, SPY gained 26.35%, GLD 24% 
  In 2010, SPY gained 15.06, GLD gained 29% 
   In Oct 2008, at the beginning of the financial crisis, GLD lost 16% 
 Hardly a good showing for "insurance" 
   IMO, if you want to own gold, it should be thought of a part of a diversified portfolio, rather than "insurance"

 Granted, their point was that one needed to look at the whole picture instead of just the last return, but comparing the arithmetic averages of the return seems misleading to me (especially after the earlier videos on common mistakes people make) 
  It seems to me that the average return should be computed as follows:  Stock A: ( (1 + 1%) * (1 + 1%) * (1 + 13%))^(1/3) - 1 = 4.85% Stock B: ((1 + 13%) * (1+3%) * (1 + 2%))^(1/3) - 1 = 5.89%

 Using definition of "comparable firms" 
  We suppose that the comparable firms have the same operating risk (from the same industry) and similar stage of development (expected growth rate) will have relevant (to multiples) price in the stock market 
 For P/E multiples we also suppose that the comparable firms have a similar financial structure (financial leverage) 
   Were there instances in history where you would not have felt comfortable using multiple-based valuation methods to value companies 
 I am a software engineer (from financial technology company, by the way) and I can refer to an example of the Instant Messenger programs (Skype, Viber, Telegram, WhatsApp) 
  It is the same industry (IT) and the same sub-industry (end-user, IM), and there is just a little different stage of development 
 We have to exclude Skype (according to multiples) because it is older, but other IMs start in approximately same time 
 It is serious limitation of multiples method, because it is the same area and skype user experience (positive and negative) is very important for other IMs, and sometimes IMs make some steps to harvest skype auditory to own side 
 But because skype is the old company (and now is part of Microsoft), we must exclude it from our observation 
 Let us continue 
 We also must exclude Telegram, because it is own project of Pavel Durov (without external or angel investments) and we can not evaluate this project in any way.  Ok, exclude Skype and Telegram, and what do we see? The most important metric for IM is the user's auditory, it's about 1B for WatsApp and about 750M for Viber 
 Viber was sold for about $900M, while WhatsApp - about $19B (to facebook) What is the key difference 
 Why does the price differ in 19 times while user's auditory differs just about 25% 
  So, we should consider other background, such as relationship between companies 
 Facebook was in need of any IM, because IM is the important source of user's information (which is used in internet advertising) 
   Facebook considers the leaders of the local areas, and WU was (and is) the most popular messenger in Latin America 
 Finally facebook has a growth of user's auditory in Latin America because another FB-killer Orkut (popular in Latin America) has been died and there was a great concurrency between social networks (VK, FB, OK, MS) 
  Buying the WhatsApp Facebook has automatically received the auditory of Latin America, but note please it's important only for Facebook and as long as you have workable model of earnings from auditory (FB has) 
  As a result Facebook wanted a lot to receive WhatsApp and was ready to pay extraordinary $19B. It is the reason of 20-times difference between WhatsApp and Viber, and we can NOT explain this phenomena using multiples method

What would you say about the market valuation when S&P 500 is trading at 2,500  
  What would you say when S&P 500 is trading at 2,000 3 years later 
 Think about valuation like how you would think about buying a new pair of shoes - you are valuing it by thinking , how much utility (reward/enjoyment/comfort) you are deriving given the price you are paying 
 Would you say you are 'valuing' the shoes by just thinking of the price of the shoes and how many pairs of shoes you are buying 
 Probably not. I suggest, when thinking about valuation, it is always good to keep in mind that you are valuing a stock by how much utility it is giving to you (In terms of dividend yield, capital appreciation, etc) per unit price you are paying

Rafael, I have had the same problems with questions 3 and 5, but finally solved them 
 I filled cells in Excel one by one with the data (fcf1, fcf2, fcf3, terminal, debt, shares) 
  I manually did DCF. Don't forget that the denominator of anything after fcf1 needs to be squared, cubed, and so on 
 In the cells beside the FCF data I actually placed the formula for this (so fcf1 gets 1.11, fcf2 gets =1.11^2, fcf3 gets =1.11^3) 
  Don't round the result 
 I then manually solved the problem on excel with this formula: =(B12/C12)+(B13/C13)+((B14+B15)/C14) Cell contents are: B12=fcf1; c12=1.11; b13=fcf2;c13=1.11^2; b14=fcf3; b15=terminal value of 6000; c14=1.11^3 You should get a result of 5314.3349 Subtract debt of 1000 (btw, I kept missing this and couldn't figure out why I couldn't get the answer right) 
  Then divide the result by the number of shares 
 You should get 43.14 
 Round to 43 
 After that, answer to question 5 should be straightforward 
 Hope this helps

The depression which resulted from the sub-prime crisis had a very sobering effect on banks 
 I do not wish to rely too heavily on that weakest of props, the stereotype, but most bankers are sober individuals who realize the vast responsibility over billions of dollars which they have 
 While I am not a "classic" economist, and am more than happy to explore the many events where too orthodox of an approach to economics has fallen down, I sense that in the lead up to the crisis of 2008 there was widespread economic amnesia 
 Many sectors of the public, and certainly more than bankers, were talking absolute rubbish ; they spoke up the arrival of a period of boom which would be like no other, and which would continue apace, holding in defiance notions of an inevitable bust 
 (Of the existence of similar types in London in 1720 or Amsterdam in the late 1630s they seemed remarkably ignorant.) I am a resident of the Irish Republic, location of a property-based "bubble", yet I and others were castigated as latter-day Cassandras when we advised restraint 
 But to return to the question, I think that central bankers and bankers in general, were genuinely shocked at the extent of the decline which occurred 
 They do not see future government intervention as something which they can rely on in future 
 Such intervention is equivalent to a massive vote of "no confidence" in the banking community, and bankers (like others) have their pride 
 There is also a new generation of central banker, typified by Mark Carney, head of the Bank of England, whose sober calmness is match by humanity

It was put forth in the lecture to use gold to protect against black swans 
 And that it hedges against market crashes, political strife, inflationary environments, and loose monetary policy 
 It's return since 1971 has been 8.5% 
   So how much to allocate to gold 
 I would argue only as much as you need 1) for insurance to get by in doomsday scenario, and 2) for bragging rights 
 [Disclaimer 
 Quick and dirty math ahead via eyeballing charts]  While gold returned 8.5% since 1971, much of that was in the 70's as the USD was decoupled from the gold standard, and then again the 10-yr period beginning 2001 with 9/11 and the Middle East 
 If I invested when I was born in 1980 after gold came off it's peak, I would have had a 0% or negative return adjusted for inflation even until today; compare that to the S&P, where I would have a substantial return ~900% 
   If I invested when gold bottomed in 2001, however, gold would outperform the S&P by 3:1 
 Looking at the chart for gold, we see it moves through long trends of positive or negative returns, and much of how gold performs as an investment depends on your starting reference point in one of these trends 
 If you bought into gold just 2-3 years after the bottom in 2001, you would have missed a substantial part of it's returns over the run-up 
 So what is gold's long-term performance 
 After all, CAPM uses long term returns and risks 
 Going back 200 years and adjusting for inflation:  $1 in USD would give you ~$0.06 today, $1 in Gold would give you $1.95, and Stocks would give you $755,163. (Forbes May 26, 2013) 
   Looking at these long-term rates and risks, gold has had lower returns and higher risks; its average returns are just above that of inflation 
 In terms of an investment on its own, it did poorly, but certainly acted as a store of value far exceeding cash 
 However, any CAPM tangent portfolio created that includes gold and is created from this data, could achieve higher returns and lower risk by excluding gold completely 
 (The same was true of holding currency.)  Based solely on this, it's proper allocation in your portfolio would be 0% 
  So where is the merit 
 As emphasized, as insurance against black swans, and accepting a the opportunity cost of lower returns 
 In terms of insurance, you aren't looking at the upside gains and getting rich off of insurance 
 It is there as a means to protect against the downside 
 How much insurance do you pay? 
   Often 2 - 10% of the asset value; anything more seems psychological and the enjoyment of owning 
 Alternatively, how much would you need if a currency were to collapse and you needed to get through and re-establish 
 This could possibly also be the target value for allocation; which possibly corresponds closely to the insurance amount you would carry

Subtracting the one means we are taking out whatever we started with to find out our actual return 
 Let's drop the '$' 
  If you start with 95, and in a year you have 95, how much did you earn 
 95/95 = 1 
 That means you ended up with 1 = 100% of what you started with, but nothing more 
 95/95 - 1 = 1 - 1 = 0, means you earned 0% 
  If you start with 100 and end up with 90, 90/100 = 90% (we certainly didn't make 90%, did we?) 
   We ended up with 90% of what we started with 
 90/100 - 1 = -10%, so we lost money

Risk Determination  A more accurate method is do use other measures like Variances, Covariances for 2 types of assets in addition to Correlations to decide whether two assets move together, or optimally move in opposite directions to diversify 
 Use Excel sheets functions to do the following: 1- Calculate the average of past returns 2- Calculate Variances 3- Calculate Volatilities (Which are the square root of Variances) These are accurate measures of return dispersion in relation to the average past returns 4- Use Covariance and Correlations functions  Correlation = Covariance/Vol (Asset 1) * Vol (Asset 2) This will give you a much better indicator

Hi Tran 
 The reasoning of Poloko is correct 
 In Michel's example, the timeline is important:   First he holds a bond with an annual coupon rate of 2% (say he bought it at 1000$ an it yields 20$ each year) 
    Then a new bond from the same issuer and the same time to maturity comes into existence and is issued at a price of 1000$ and a yearly coupon of 30$ 
    The two bonds will not coexist at the same price because they are perfectly identical, except for their yield 
 Thus the bond Michel holds has to drop in price to remain equally attractive as the new bond to other investors 
 And so it will drop in price to a level so that it also yields 3% 
  The intuitive reasoning behind this is that two assets that provide the same cash flows must have the same price 
 I hope this helps 
 Best regards, Jonas

Good points Abelardo 
 On Gold, I use it as long term insurance (LTI) 
  not as an investment 
 Both methods need a valuation Monetarily, Gold @ $1,181/oz and global supply at ~5.9 Billion oz 
 We have ~$7Trillion in gold 
 Well, if the  Global M1 money supply is $20Trillion & M2 is $48Trillion 
  The price of gold needs to increase 10X.  Possibility-perhaps 
 As we know from Accounting,  cash assets +  non-cash assets =liabilities +owners equity 
 So, increase one side and the other side must also go up 
 Any takers for either side 
 Let's use F&C's (Floors & Ceilings) 
  Take an exchange traded fund (ETF) like GLD and tract it for the highs (Ceilings) & lows (Floors) 
   As LTI.  one can   use F&C's over a long period of time (historical of course) and buy GLD near the low. Later when the price reaches an amount you are comfortable with (insurance wise) 
  sell it and put in in a safe place until you need it 
 As an investment, similar process 
 But here one needs to determine their Minimum acceptable Rate Of Return (MARR) + use F&C's to follow a trend that produces your MARR 
 This may be short or long term 
 Keep in mind that long term may be a very long time 
 So choose wisely 
 Now, if all you want is to get a market return 
 Then, why are you looking at GLD? just use SPY. This is an ETF that tracks the S&P 500 (an indicator of the Market) 
  They are both volatile but the SPY is more stable 
 Depending on your time horizon 
 One may be more advantageous than the other 
 Historical F&C's 1) 
  Buy  GLD in 2010  @ $100. Sell in 2012 @ $175 for a 32% CAGR (Compound Annual Growth Rate) 
   2) 
   Buy  GLD in 2010  @ $100. Sell in Feb 2016 @ $114 for a 2% CAGR (Compound Annual Growth Rate) 
  3) 
  Buy  GLD in Jan 2016 @ $105.  In Feb 2016 it is $114. This is 8.57%  Bottom line 
 Be realistic (rational), understand your needs first 
 Invest much later

Hi Veronika, Question 2 As it on both valuation methods it only says "JUST" and it doesn't combined both approaches ie comparing the the price of the securities within the index with their relevant earning in order to estimate whether that index as a whole has become more cheaper or expensive we can discount those two answers 
 However, the other two answers are correct because "expensive" & "cheaper" index can always become both more so depending if the earnings of the companies within this index move in a greater proportion (percentage) than the price move of the index 
 Question 8 The correct answers are: A) Over this time\nperiod, there was a greater chance of observing extremely bad monthly returns\n(more negative than -20%) than extremely good monthly returns (more positive\nthan 20%) 
  B) Over this time period, there was a 80% chance of observing a monthly\nreturn between -10% and 10% 
  Rationale: A) is correct because if we look at the histogram there are no observations on the right side, where the returns have been more than +20% 
  B) is correct because if we combine the frequency of the two histogram bars, which are both 40% we end up with 80% of all observation of the data 
 I hope this helps 
 Kind regards, Stoyan

I think it depends on what you are hedging against and what you want this hedge (insurance) to accomplish 
 I tend to think of insurance as something I purchase in case a certain event happens 
 The more likely the event - the more expensive the insurance (e.g 
 Health and auto insurance), the less likely the cheaper the policy (e.g 
 Fire insurance) 
   However,  hedging is not quite the same 
 You are buying gold because historically it is uncorrelated with certain events - but the magnitude of this seems unpredictable 
 In the "Gold as a hedge against stock market crashes" example in the lecture you would need to have 50% in gold to offset a crash - which seems like way too much money  = however if you were looking to simply ease the pain of this event - then the "How much gold" question would be very much based on one's tolerance for pain 
 E.g 
 100 in stocks becomes 60 after a 40% decline, 90/10 stocks to gold would become 68 (assuming -40/+40) and 80/20 would yield 76 in this scenario 
 If your "pain" tolerance is high - zero gold seems fine, and as it gets lower - add more gold

0, 1, 2, 3, 4 is the time, in this case it's years 
 In year 1 you spent 150 ("-150" in the chart) 
  In Year 1 you assume a cash inflow of 20, in year 2 an inflow of 50 etc.  These are cash flows in the future and you have to "discount" them to their present value (see   
  Here the discount rate is given as 10% (please don't ask me how to determine a reasonable discount rate in a real life situation. 
 ) The investment of the present does not need to be discounted, therefore we take it as -150.  The cash inflow of year 1 needs to be discounted with the discount rate ot 10% per year, for the duration of 1 year 
 10%=0.1, the discount formula for 1 year is "inflow of year 1 / (1+discount rate) 
  Filling in the numbers: 20/(1+0.1) = 20/1.1 = 20/1.10 = 18.181818 
 The inflow of year 2 needs to be discounted with the discount rate of 10% per year, for the duration of 2 years, that means "inflow / [(1+discount rate)*(1+discount rate)]" 
  That is the same as "inflow / [(1+discount rate)]^2" 
  Filling in the numbers: 50/[1.10^2] 
   Generally speaking the discount formula is "inflow of year N / [(1+discount rate)^N] 
  You do that for each year and sum it all up

The question is posed as an “either/or”
choice, as if we only have to be concerned with one or the other of the
outcomes 
 On the contrary, from what I
have studied (1), I believe that the American authorities had no choice but to
act as they did, and that Moral Hazard and lack of responsible regulation has
to be a continuing concern, regardless of any effects from the actions taken 
 The actions taken, 2007-2009: The actions
were not taken just for the well-being of the economy – as if they were addressing
only a sort of economic cough; the crisis of 2008 was a major systemic
crisis which would have degenerated into another depression equal to the Great
Depression of 1929 (2) 
  In fact, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC)
did take some “haircut” actions initially, only to realize that they were making
the crisis worse 
 The paradox, as Timothy Geithner - American Secretary of the
Treasury at the time - has noted, is that, to prevent the enormous damage
threatened by a major systemic crisis, one is forced to do the opposite
of what is normally required in a minor crisis; despite the Moral Hazard that
this implies 
 Finally, we should not forget the positive side: the actions
taken seem to have brought the American economy into positive recovery zone
within 4 years; which appears to be an impressive record when compared to the
aftermath of other world crises (1) 
    Potential Consequences of Actions Taken:
the argument that the actions taken only “incentivized banks to be careless”
seems to be somewhat simplified 
 Consider that:  ·     
Such an assumption is not an obvious
conclusion 
 After all, the American authorities did let a number of companies
fail: Lehman Brothers (too big to be allowed to fail class) and other
institutions such as IndyMac and Washington Mutual 
 This leaves a doubt: who
would be protected in the future 
 ·     
Companies that are bailed out are
still required to repay the amounts advanced; ·     
The reforms contained in the
Dodd Frank Act (2010) address many of the defects in the system; ·     
The actions taken in 2007-2009
did not initiate the Risk of Moral Hazard 
 This has always been a concern and
will continue to be 
 We have learned to
control certain crises but the actors in the system are forever innovating and
will find new ways of creating Risk 
 Even now the push is on for President
Trump to repeal Dodd Frank 
 Some of the concluding comments of Secretary
Geithner (1) are relevant: “Risk will find its way around … constraints 
 Risk
can migrate”; and “Don’t have too much confidence in the power of the
regulatory safeguards”

Good analogy Abelardo 
 To add to what Abelardo posted 
 My thoughts are going foreward,  you can not un-ring a bell 
 A better question could be, why did our regulators allow these synthetic CDOs & CDS to begin with and what is an appropriate fiscally responsible strategy 
 In the US we now have more regulatory hurdles like Dodd-Frank, Basel accords, etc.  Some good and some not. Dodd Frank becomes more restrictive for small & medium banks in the coming years 
 Basel Accords are similar 
 A small bank ($1B) with a 4.5% RWA (Risk Weighted Assets) + 2.5% CCB (Capital Conservation Buffer) + 2.5% CB (Counter Cyclical Buffer) is severely hobbled when compared to a large bank ($50B)  with the same requirements 
 Historical case in point: Merger of Citicorp (commercial bank holding company) with Travelers (Insurance company) in 1998 
 This violated The Glass-Stegall Act of 1956 
 The Federal Reserve gave Citigroup a temporary waiver in 1998.\n Less than a year later, the GLBA ( Gramm-Leach-Biley-Act)  was passed to legalize these on a permanent basis 
 US President Barack Obama has stated that GLBA led to deregulation that,\n among other things, allowed for the creation of giant financial \nsupermarkets that could own investment banks, commercial banks and \ninsurance firms, something banned since the Great Depression of 1929 
 Many others also say it cleared the way for companies that were  to big and interconnected to fail thus requiring massive bailouts to remain solvent 
 The Nobel prize  winning Economist Joseph Stigiltz has also argued that the GBLA helped to create the banking crisis  To be fair 
 It is also true  that the US banking system was becoming less competitive on the international circuit 
 So, reform was needed 
 However,  it is one thing for an Ikea like storefront to offer goods & services from A to Z under one roof 
 It is an entirely different matter for banks to offer their customers these A to Z goods & services under one roof with uncontrolled  leverage or by bundling them with a synthetic wrapper just because they wanted to find a way to make more money 
 As Einstein foretold; the mistake with uncertainty  is the belief that there is an antidote 
 My bottom line: The bailout should not have been necessary and we need a culture of both appropriate regulations and fiscal responsibility to ensure that we work together using a multidisciplinary approach rather than a nail & hammer ideology 
 Cheers

Its the compound interest Formula 
 
The formula for annual compound interest, including principal sum, is:
A = P (1 + r/n) (nt) 
 
Where:
 
A = the future value of the investment/loan, including interest
P = the principal investment amount (the initial deposit or loan amount)
r = the annual interest rate (decimal)
n = the number of times that interest is compounded per year
t = the number of years the money is invested or borrowed for  In our case n=1, as the compounding is annual 
 We know A= the final amount, P=the principal we started with and t=time 
 We need to calculate R which comes to around 9% in the quiz

(1) Any multiples-based measures that are based upon current/short term quantities (such as the current year's earnings) will be subject to any short term off-trend anomalies in those quantities 
 Such measures may, for example, be biased downwards by adverse economics conditions, that is to say that they might be unduly pessimistic because they do not take into account the possibility of an economic recovery 
 (2) Reporting a current loss, will make a nonsense of some measures such as P/E ratio 
 (3) Finally, if the "comparable" companies are few in number, their ratios could be statistically insignificant, i.e 
 The mean ratio(s) could be unduly influenced by the particular circumstance of those few companies, meaning that there is essentially no point in using them for comparison

 To let them go bust would cause an enormous ripple effect in the economy which could plunge the US into a greater depression for many years 
 The bailout of 2008 might have seemed unfair to allow banks to get away with carelessness, but it has also awakened the American people to the dangers and perils of finance 
 You can the shift has been that younger generations are shying away from mortgages and buying homes because of what they saw in 2008, and instead are shifting to renting 
 But they are also shifting to investing more of their money elsewhere 
 The free market and its participants figured out a way to help themselves, while also penalizing the banks in the large term 
 It's not so easy to sell someone on a mortgage, and it's unlikely banks will ever see the level of borrowing for housing they did during the 80's and 90's

Multiples-based earnings methods have a few drawbacks: 1) The P/E ratio will often be subject to accounting judgements that may distort the earnings 
 For example if a company has posted a significant reduction in profits due to the requirement to recognise a large provision, that will alter the earnings for the year and impact the P/E ratio but in actual fact the business hasn't fundamentally changed and may otherwise actually have been more profitable 
 2) They assume that the company will continue to generate value for its shareholders at the rate it has been; it doesn't take forward looking data into account very well 
 3) It assumes that the companies are similar enough in nature that the ratios are relevant 
 4) If you report a loss then you get a negative value of the company 
 This isn't necessarily true

1 
 Negative earning reported by company 
 2 
 No precise data about companies (companies are not public, etc) in industry 
 3 
 Changes in future are not taken into account

PE Ratio is how much investors are paying for a dollar of earnings TODAY 
 For example, one stock is available for $10 
 It earns $1 
 It has a PE of 10 
 You're paying $10 for a $1 in earnings 
 Another stock in the same industry is $20 
 Earnings are also $1 
 It has a PE of 20 
 You're paying $20 for a $1 in earnings 
 Which stock is cheap and which is expensive based on what you have paid for $1 of earnings 
 You're more likely to have a profitable investment if you have not "overpaid" 
  Earnings are what drives the growth of a business 
 With their earnings, a company invests in new buildings and equipment, buy other businesses, pay dividends, etc. The earnings are not directly paid to investors, but are put to work in the  business that will, hopefully, earn a high rate of return 
 This is why we invest in stocks 
 This is why, in the future, other investors will buy our shares  for more than we paid 
 We don't know what our future ROI will be when we make an investment 
 We have to make  investing decisions based on what we know today

1) we assume the ratios are based on pure financial values, while other external/internal factors could impact on these values like financial crises, industry crises, M&A, investments, mortgages, etc. 2) as said, financial crises like 2007-2009, but also Amazon extraordinary revenue based on cloud services AWS revenues or when Vivendi bought a big slice of Mediaset shares 
 3) ratios could not be used and multiple-based valuation would be useful to understand how far is the Company from being in the arena

The first part of the decision is what amount (in USD) we cannot afford to lose 
 Let's say we have total wealth of 100,000 and the iron reserve is 30,000. That already tells us that gold should be at a minimum of 30% 
  There is no point to weigh by probability of black swans here, because the definition of "iron reserve" is that under any circumstances can it be risked 
 Let's make two further assumptions: (a) the observed historic rate of return of non-gold portfolio is 10% and (b) in case of a black swan we lose 75% of our capital invested in non-gold assets 
 So now we have 70,000 USD remaining risk capital 
 If we include another 10,000 USD in gold out of that risk capital we are losing the upside opportunity, which is equal to the share of gold out of the risk money X the observed historic return in other investments, i.e.:   Share of gold out of risk capital = 10 / 70 = 14%\n   Historic return of portfolio ex 
 Gold = 10%\n   Then the opportunity cost of this 10K invested in gold is 1.4pp negative of the final return\n   This opportunity cost would increase as we increase the share of gold, e.g 
 If we invest everything in gold, the opportunity cost would be equal to 100%x10% = 10pp negative - what we would have made if we invested everything in non-gold portfolio 
 (The opportunity cost for the initial 30,000 USD iron reserve allocation is 0% because it is not really an option to invest it, therefore nothing to lose by holding it.) If for a moment we assume that black swan cannot happen, increasing the gold position to about 45K (on top of the initial 30k) we will get 0% return precisely because of the opportunity cost, therefore gold should not exceed that dollar amount 
 On the other extreme if we want to maximize our returns we should invest all 70,000 in non-gold assets 
 Three final considerations:   If we believe that the probability of a black swan is above ~13% (the cut off point using the assumptions above) we should not invest in the stock market at all, as the probability-weighted loss from a black swan will wipe out the probability-weighted investment returns.\n   The percentage share of gold in our portfolio also depends on the size of the entire portfolio, e.g 
 If we have $500,000 capital to invest and iron reserve requirement of $50,000 this gives us minimum gold requirement of 10% (unlike the 30% in the first example) 
    We may argue that in a black swan scenario we will not lose everything (e.g 
 We will save 25% of 70,000 = 17,500) and therefore our iron reserve should be 30 - 17.5 = 12.5, but that really depends on the interpretation of 'iron' in iron reserve and 'black' in black swan 
 \n

Long term  Equities appear to offer better returns , so you should be 100% vested in Equities, however my own risk tolerance would be concerned with short term volatility for the more extreme market moves (greater than 10%)

estimate:                                G = ((100- A)* I)/4

Recent stock market history  is full of "isolated" instances 
 I've invested through the 1987 crash, late 90s tech bubble, 2008 financial crisis, and many more "isolated" instances 
 Young investors have "rose-colored glasses" view of the market 
 They only know a stock market that goes up 
 It is much different to look at a 50% stock market drop on a chart than it is to see on your brokerage statement 
 With an investing lifetime of 60 to 70 years, an investor is going to see many scary markets 
 Looking at past performance, would not have warned of  less $30 barrel oil for oil companies and drillers 
 Past performance would not have warned of the bankruptcies of GM, Bear Stearns, Lehman Brothers, or AIG or accounting scandals of Waste Management, Worldcom, Enron, etc. Past performance would not have warned of Japan's economic problems 
 Looking at past performance is ok, but it may not foretell the future

  The terminal value Vn is used for an extended forecast horizon longer than say 5 years simplifying our assumptions that these future cash flows that are further away in future are growing at a constant rate gFCF  Vn= ((1+gFCF)/(rWACC-gFCF))*FCFN Where FCFn is the Future cash flow of the last period year given  Now to calculate the price of one share we need the Firm Value which is represented by V0 Vo= (FCF/(1+rWACC))+(FCF2/(1+rWACC)^2))+ 
 +(FCFn+Vn/(1+rWACC)^n) Now once we get the firm value we can now calculate the price of one share Po by subtracting the value of debt of the firm and dividing the number by total no of outstanding shares

 Your p/share is lower by price than mine but what is the value 
 This is what I generally use for valuing an exchange listed firm (obviously, this is very different from WACC & EV) 
   Calculating the sticker price and Margin Of Safety (MOS) 1 
 Use the current EPS-TTM (Trailing 12 Months) 2 
 Select a growth rate (analysts, historical BVPS, or your own) 3 
 Obtain Future EPS by Growing EPS for 10 years (use calculator or rule of 72) 4 
 Determine future P/E (Price/Earnings) multiple (2x the growth rate from #2 or double historical P/E-conservative) Maximum of 50 5 
 Multiply future EPS and future P/E to get future sticker price 6 
 Default MARR (Minimal Accepted Rate of Return) is 15% 7 
 Discount future sticker price by MARR 
 Then divide by 4 =sticker price 8 
 MOS is 50% 9 
 Multiply the sticker price by 50% (MOS) = MOS price 10 
 Determine current market price 11 
 Is stock available under MOS price 
 12 
 If yes, consider purchasing   Hope this helps

Dear Kasper, This is a trick question because the problem in the quiz was about Price/Earnings ratio and you must ignore the debt in your answer 
 However in the lecture, the example was different, because Professor Valta was talking about the EBITDA multiple, and in this case, you must use the debt in your calculation 
 The Classic Definition of EBITDA multiple is: Value/EBITDA = (Market value of equity + Market value of debt) / (Earnings before Interest, Taxes and Depreciation) The example in the lecture was: (Equity USD 102,168 + Debt USD 125) / (EBITDA USD 30,7) = 7,4 which is our Multiple 
 Best regards

A P/E ratio is basically just the price you are paying (for the stock) per dollar of earnings of a company 
 So if a P/E is 20, you are paying 20x the earnings of the company for that stock 
 So, say a stock is selling for $50, and it has a P/E of 25 
 If the stock goes down to $40, the earnings of the company haven't changed; yet you are paying less for the stock 
 So you are paying less for the company which is still as strong as before 
 You will be paying a lower _price_ for that same _equity_, i.e 
 P.E

You just use the formula where you multiply the ratio by the earnings and then, divide by number of shares

  Though it will cost me a point, I will not answer the question of week 1 regarding return/risk ratio (whether one should choose the country with the highest ratio) with yes. It is just plain wrong 
 Asymptotically, when the risk goes to zero, the risk becomes irrelevant (i.e.: the growth equals (1+x)^n, with n the number of years, with ignorable spread) 
  For small enough n, it does not matter whether the risk is 0.1% or 0.01%, and one will just choose the highest return 
 What would you rather choose: a return of 10% with a risk of 1% or a return of 1% with a risk of 0.01% 
  Under no circumstance the latter, I presume 
 (and that doesn't even have to do with inflation)

A number of things are wrong with this analysis;  to mention just two : 1 
 The Fed funds rate is not the same as the interest rate at which investors get paid; that  interest rate is determined by other factors 
 E.g 
 2004-2006 Fed funds rate went up, long term rates went down (don't take my word for it,  Alan Greenspan referred to this dichotomy as  a "conundrum." 2  
 " Money printing" is a misleading term,  really what's happening is the addition of bank reserves in an attempt to stimulate lending, i.e 
 Quantitative easing 
 These actions has not led to inflation, the banks are trying to inflate the currency but have not been successful in doing so 
 (Again, don't take my word for it--Ben Bernnake has explicitly said of QE: it's not printing money, currency in circulation has not gone up.)

 Jones was the first with few competitors 
 Today, there are many hedge funds and mutual funds trying to accomplish the same thing 
 As a small investor, you can't hope to compete in the big leagues 
 They have more education, more data, more experience, more time, and more money 
 Annual reports, Financial Times, and the Wall Street Journal contain information that is already known and been acted upon 
 That doesn't mean you can't still be a successful investor 
 Over the last few years,  the average hedge fund has had  very poor returns 
 Mutual fund managers seldom are able to beat their index 
 However, the small investors can beat these money manager's returns by buying an S&P500 index fund

 They contain a lot of investing wisdom

Nathan, in finance, investors prefer assets with positive (right) skewness in the return distribution 
 In that case ​a return distribution will be characterized by frequent small losses and a few large gains 
 However, all four moments (mean, standard deviation, skewness and​s) are important 
 In general, people are risk averse 
 So, keeping  mean,variance and kurtosis constant, positive skewness is preferable, because while a small chance of large wins might not be that good, a small chance of large losses is still really bad.  For more info you can check the following link: 1
